name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the joint debate on gender balance, the question with request for an oral reply to the Council on ' Women at the helm of businesses', by Iratxe García Pérez, Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann, Evelyn Regner and Anna Hedh (O-000123/2018 - B8-0002/2019) (2019/2513(RSP).

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Author. – Mr President, the lack of representation of women in the different spheres of social, political, economic life is the symptom of an unequal society, is the symptom of the need to advance policies of equality between men and women. It was in 2013 that this Parliament positioned the European Commission's proposal on the representation of women on the board of directors to incorporate mandatory quotas for women's representation in the business spheres, so that we too in the field of economics have equal representation.  It's been five years. They have passed the presidency after presidency with a blockade on the Council, where national governments have been unable to sit at the table and understand that moving forward in a more equal Europe is also advancing in a Europe where women's representation is a reality in all areas.  And there had to be a change in the Spanish Government to also drive change in the Council and to try to ensure that there is finally an agreement in this regard.  I would like to thank Mrs Jourová for the impetus she is giving me to, from the Commission and together with the Council and Parliament, to enable us to end this parliamentary term with an equality initiative which is essential.  Because we can't resign ourselves to women's rights remaining in reverse. Because we need women to be represented on equal opportunities and that is why this Parliament has to position itself in a very clear way and ask the Romanian presidency to make one last effort, that we have the possibility, that we have the capacity, that there are governments, such as Spain, which have decided to promote this initiative, that women want to be part of decision-making and that it is essential to move forward in a more equal Europe and fairer.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: author. – Mr President, this is a very important moment: it is time to conclude that there is no reason whatsoever not to adopt the directive of 2012 which would make it an obligation for listed companies to reach the minimum 40% share of persons of either sex among their non—executive board members. I’m very surprised that some Member States should still be referring to subsidiarity. How can they do that? We have European companies that operate not only in Europe but also beyond it, so this should definitely be an issue for European Union competence. Secondly, we know very well that diversity in all its dimensions – and gender is an important dimension of diversity – expands companies’ views and perspectives in terms of understanding what’s going on in the world and reacting to it in their business strategies. Thirdly, there’s no reason whatsoever to say that there are no competent women. That is an excuse for a male—dominated corporate culture in which women are not visible because, perhaps, they do not always share this male—dominated corporate culture and its behaviour patterns. However, it is certain that the competence of women to respond to today’s challenges is at least the same as that of men. There has been ample time for Member States to proceed, in voluntary ways, with measures for diversity and for women on company boards, but still we were in a situation where, in 2017 and 2018, women accounted only for 26.3% of board members in the largest publicly listed companies registered in the EU. There is a huge discrepancy – from 7.4% to 43% – and this discrepancy shows that we need measures at European level to advance towards harmonisation of this important aspect. I would like to thank the Spanish Government for finally taking a second look at this question. And maybe, with the Romanian Presidency of the Council, we can now finally conclude this matter and can declare, before the European elections, that the European Union is actively promoting a modern cooperate culture which includes contributions from both women and men. There’s no reason to say that there are no competent women.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is a great pleasure to join everyone here today for this important debate. I want to begin by saying that gender equality lies at the heart of the Council’s vision of social Europe. The Council’s commitment to equality between women and men has been strongly affirmed in many declarations, as well as in the legislation that we have developed over the years together with Parliament.  I would also like to recall the European pillar of social rights, which was jointly proclaimed by Parliament, the Council and the Commission in November 2017. Gender equality has pride of place in this document, and I quote ‘equality of treatment and opportunities between women and men must be ensured and fostered in all areas, including regarding participation in the labour market, terms and conditions of employment and career progression. Women and men have the right to equal pay for work of equal value’. This commitment of course echoes the EU Treaties and our existing legislation but this issue should not be left aside.  Despite the enormous progress that has been made over the past half century and more, equality in practice continues to elude us. Let me give you an example. There is still a large gender pay gap in Europe. The average gender pay gap is 16.2% according to Eurostat and women’s gross hourly pay is still lower than men’s. This of course is not equality. We will address the gender pay gap in a set of Council conclusions that we hope to see adopted at the EPSCO Council in June.  In order to deliver on the promise contained in the pillar of social rights, we need continued and determined action on the part of the Commission, the co—legislators and the Member States. Honourable Members, today you have asked us to comment more specifically on the Commission’s proposal for a directive on improving the gender balance on company boards. I regret to say that – as of course you know – there is still a blocking minority in the Council. The most recent meeting on the file took place under the Maltese Presidency in 2017, and the proposal has not been formally discussed by the Council since. As things stand right now, the file remains blocked. Nevertheless, there is broad consensus in Europe on the need to improve the gender balance on company boards. Although the Member States have different approaches the principle is not contested. In this vein, the Romanian Presidency aims to facilitate discussions at the Council level in order to explore possible ways forward.  I would also like to mention the proposal for a directive on work—life balance for parents and caretakers. Here we have better news. Indeed, I’m glad to say that negotiations between the Council and Parliament led to a provisional agreement at the sixth trilogue, which took place on 24 January. This success was made possible also by the excellent progress that was achieved under both the Bulgarian and Austrian Presidencies.  Facilitating work—life balance is a vital part of social and employment policies. We must do all we can to help our citizens reconcile work and private life. This is all the more important in the context of the demographic situation and labour market changes. On the one hand, we need to make sure that Europe’s highly educated, highly skilled women are able to take advantage of labour market opportunities. This makes obvious economic sense. It is also a matter of equal rights. On the other hand, European women and men should be able to have children without having to choose between being a parent and having a job. I would like to point out that, more often than not, women are the ones faced with this decision. This is only feasible if workers with families have adequate leave rights and if those rights are extended to both women and men.  Meanwhile, it is also necessary to respect the diversity of the national systems in place. In Europe, it is never the case that one size fits all – least of all in the field of employment and family policy where traditions, economic realities and social assistance vary very greatly between the Member States. We must respect the principle of subsidiarity.  These were some of the considerations we had to address in the negotiations on the work—life balance directive. It was not easy, but I am pleased that we found a solution that raised the minimum standards in Europe, yet gives the Member States the necessary flexibility. I thank Parliament for its cooperation on this file. Thank you for your attention.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the European Parliament for putting the important topic of women’s rights and gender equality in the EU on the agenda today. I am very grateful for your overwhelming support for the Commission’s proposal aiming to improve gender balance on the corporate boards of the largest EU listed companies.  I have now been Commissioner for Gender Equality for almost five years. While I am proud of our collective work, in particular about the recent finalisation of the work—life balance package, I remain concerned, as the European Institute for Gender Equality states in its largest and latest Gender Equality Index, that in some areas we are moving at a snail’s pace. When we were publishing the latest figures I didn’t hide my big disappointment about this slow development, in spite of all the efforts we are investing. The Gender Equality Index shows that gender equality in decision—making continues to have the lowest score of all domains evaluated in the index, and this despite some national legislation which have been adopted in the meantime. We are all aware of the studies, which clearly show the benefits of diversity on boards – benefits for business and for society alike, of course. The Commission remains committed to the proposed Women on Boards Directive. Despite their capabilities and educational achievements, women continue to struggle against long—held and systemic entry barriers onto corporate boards and leadership positions.  The proposed directive will enable us to decisively widen the access of talented women to decision—making positions and to accelerate economic growth. With women in power, a snowball effect will be created towards more gender equality.  I would like to recall that this is a flexible and proportionate proposal. It is a good example of subsidiarity—friendly legislation, which offers Member States considerable flexibility in how to achieve the progress. It is also legislation that is gender neutral; it deals with adjustments regarding the under—represented sex in the case of similar levels of qualification, be they men or women. It deals with an overall objective and Member States are free to keep and apply their own existing effective measures aimed at improving gender balance in corporate boards.  According to our figures the states which have the legislation make progress; those states which do not have any legislation are just stagnating.  So we see the positive impact of legislation in many examples. The Commission’s proposal enjoys wide support from the European Parliament, and I want to thank you for this support once again. It also enjoys the support of a majority of the Member States.  In my view, a general approach is within reach. I can only repeat what has been said here also, that there is an important development, which was done by the Spanish Government. I was in Spain recently and there is very strong determination among the members of the government, including the Prime Minister, to move on and to convince also the states which are still opposing this piece of legislation.  Of course, I also rely very much on the Romanian Presidency, which is very determined as well.  I am ready to engage, in the run—up to the March EPSCO Council, with the Member States to try to unblock the negotiations in the Council. The Minister also mentioned here the June Council and, well, we have to have a serious debate about how to tackle the – I would say shameful – issue of the gender pay gap, which is also still very high in Europe. So the Commission trusts the Romanian Presidency will invest substantial efforts in this important dossier and actively pursue the discussions with a view to a possible compromise solution.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: At this stage we can no longer accept "Blue card" questions due to time problems.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for According to the voices so far, it seems that we all agree – and the European Commission, and the European Parliament, and the current Presidency – we all support this directive. Moreover, in fact, no Member State disputes the purpose of this directive, so one can ask ourselves: why is it not yet present and why in some Member States the presence of women on boards, in the highest boards of listed companies of large companies is only 7%? If the argument for subsidiarity were true and sincere, member states would put in place solutions that would eliminate this disparity. After all, no one in their right mind thinks that such a disparity as 7% – 93% or 3% – 97%, as in the case of a CEO, is due to a difference in talent or competence. It is clear that there are other mechanisms in place to respond to, and apparently, because there are no effects at Member State level, this response must come out of the European Union level. I strongly support this directive – the excellent directive by Commissioner Viviane Reding – and it is high time that it was the competences, not the other factors, that decided the appointment of people to the highest positions. I would remind you that this directive speaks of transparent recruitment rules, that vacancies for such high positions have clearly defined criteria, that we know how this process is taking place, and that this should not be done on the basis of the selection of school year calendar colleagues, but that it is transparent and clear to all procedures. Finally, I would like to add one more thing: as a representative of the EPP, I would like to emphasise that, because for women the main obstacle to being present on the labour market and in promotion is the issue of childcare, the issue of work-life balance is absolutely crucial in this matter, which does not mean that this directive is not a necessary, important additional impetus that can be fixed. And I would just like to congratulate the current Presidency on the fact that we have effectively completed the last trilogues and call on all political groups to support this directive in the forthcoming votes.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We need capable, intelligent and capable men and women at the top of companies, on supervisory boards as well as on boards. Seven years ago, the Commission put forward a proposal on this. The European Parliament has acted very quickly. We have said that we need objective selection criteria, and we also want to be practical. We look at what the individual countries are looking like: which country has already adopted appropriate legal measures here? What has perhaps been the progress made at voluntary level? In other words, we in the European Parliament have voted very practically on the need for objective criteria, which must then be implemented, and that we do not get far with voluntary action. We need binding, and we also need a sanction mechanism so that something can finally be done here.  Equality, equality – this is something that is in the DNA of the European Union. It is only through the European Union that we have made so much progress in a great many countries, country by country. In other words, it is something wonderful for businesses, for the economy, it is a wonderful thing for men too, and that is something wonderful for women. So, and what has happened now? A great many countries are hiding behind the legal basis. What does that mean? The legal basis is absolute, because only those countries that ultimately have no progress in their own countries are hiding.  I therefore call on the Romanian Presidency, whose initiative I very much welcome, to finally turn the spotlight back on the issue of bringing those Member States that are hiding behind the curtain. Which Member States are they? These are countries like Hungary. We have now looked at what progress is going to look like: there is even a step backwards in the companies. In other words, I call on the Presidency to finally put these countries before the curtain and say what they have actually done and, if necessary, to have them voted on in a Council. The European Parliament is united here with a very strong position, and I am very glad that you have now more or less brought this proposal back to the table.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Minister, i would like to thank you very much for The issue is really very important. When we look at the gender equality index, we see that women are indeed underrepresented on company boards, underrepresented in senior positions. And then there is reflection: why is this happening? After all, women are competent, educated, hardworking, ambitious. They are definitely neither weaker nor less talented than men. So why are there so few women in senior positions? Well, in my opinion, one of the main reasons is that women build their career paths more slowly because they want to be not only great employees, but also want to be mothers. And this time when they fall out of their working lives to fulfill their maternal dreams is one of the main reasons for building a career path more slowly. So we should think about what we should do to make sure that there are indeed more women in senior positions, but not to introduce women there artificially, not mechanically, not through directives, but to propose solutions that will allow you to combine work and family life. Indeed, we need solutions that will enable us to achieve a work-life balance. And I think that such a solution and looking for such a compromise will give definitely good results.  Eurostat reports that the wage gap in the Member States varies. There are countries where this pay gap between men and women is very significant. Fortunately, Poland is in the top five Member States with the smallest wage gap, and in recent years the number of women in high-level positions has increased significantly in Poland – without mechanical artificial regulation.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Jourová, thank you very much for all the efforts and your commitment to these initiatives, but in view of the content of these questions, in view of how they block this proposal in the Council to promote equality on the board of directors, I would like to ask the European Governments for three things: coherence, vision of the future and courage. Consistency, because here we are filled with talking about smart growth, of a talent-based economy, but we do our best to ensure that half of the talent available, the one we bring women, does not go where it can be most useful. To the advice. To the decision-making centers. Where, as all studies show, it is more profitable. Where it is a success, as certified by all the experiences put in place in some Member States. Dare to look at this proposal from a profitability perspective. Because they are afraid to do so from the perspective of equality, justice and equal opportunities. Vision for the future, because Europe is one of the most sensitive and active areas of the world in equality policies. Let's take advantage of this competitive advantage. While in other spaces they begin to think of some ideas that we have been groping for years, let us bet on bringing them to their last consequences. Because, as we have said, besides fair and democratic, it is profitable. All the advantage we take from others in this talent-adding operation will make us more competitive.  And finally, bravery. There are too many men thinking about masculine at the forefront of this blockade. Shake your fear. Win. Take on what you miss: to reconcile, to take care of children, to the elderly, to share the magical task of transforming a mortgage into a home, an opportunity. You will discover that enjoying this part of life will make you happier. It will help them train their emotional intelligence. It will connect them with feelings, with experiences, with people, with problems, with responsibilities, from which they have been fleeing for centuries. I am convinced that a world with men willing to take on this challenge will be much better.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, it is very important that we try to unblock this directive. We come from a fairly standing mandate on gender equality, and it would be excellent if we could reach the end of the mandate between the Commission and the Romanian Presidency with good prospects for this directive, which has been blocked since it was introduced in 2012.  Establishing 40% of women's quotas on board of directors is essential. It is essential because economic power is central to gender equality, and also because it is a model that has worked. In Norway it has worked indisputably. It hasn't solved everything, but in today's listed companies there are 40% of women.  And it is not an issue that one can hide behind subsidiarity, as many Member States do. For two reasons: first, because gender equality is an objective set out in the Treaties and economic power is a central element in advancing equality. And secondly, because the disparity in the European Union is from 7.4 in some countries with women's presence on the board of directors to 43%. The disparity is enormous, and we therefore need a legal framework at European Union level to harmonise and promote this measure. As I said, in Norway this has been a measure that is absolutely a success. That's unquestionable. He hasn't solved everything. And we must also learn. There are two central issues. First, it is one thing to establish equality on the board of directors and the other is to achieve it in executive positions. And there we have to do work too, because a measure of these does not solve the second part, on which we must also work. And secondly, what we have learned from the Norwegian experience is that there are implementation challenges, of course, and that is why in 2013 Parliament called for a very important sanctions regime for those companies that did not meet that objective, for example by excluding them from public competitions if they did not comply with the 40% set by the Directive.  It is therefore a central legislative part of advancing equality. I would like both the Commission and the Council to try to give us good news in the coming months, because in this House I believe that support for this text is unanimous.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Why is it that only 24 out of a total of 200 board positions in German DAX companies are filled by women and that there is not a single woman at the top of these companies? Because gender equality has still not been achieved even in the EU. This is a shame! Internationally, the balance sheet is hardly better: of the 500 largest companies in the world, only 3% are managed by a woman as a member of the Executive Board. The fact that we still have to discuss this issue in 2019 is shameful and makes me seriously doubt our much-vaunted progress. Apparently, there are still many perpetually existing people who think that women are only there for reproductive purposes and belong behind the stove because they are supposedly not suitable for management functions of the economy. Do we really want to wait another 40 years? After all, it would take so long without binding rules for the proportion of women on boards and supervisory boards to rise to 40%. We do not need longer discussions. This world is not a men's world, but a world for all people, regardless of their gender. So let us finally tell the misogynistic and anachronistic thinking in the executive floors to fight!

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the Woman on Boards Directive is not only offensive but it’s patronising and condescending to those women that have earned positions at the top through merit. How utterly demeaning for a woman to find out she has been chosen for a position due to a quota and not through her accomplishments. Quotas signal to women that we are inferior and incapable of achieving success. What about women working at lower levels of companies? Quotas do not signify any increased opportunities or promotions, nor equate to more female CEOs. Despite Norway having implemented gender quota laws nearly a decade ago, only 7% of women hold executive roles.  Where do we stop? Where do these quotas stop?  First you set a quota between men and women, and what about the under-representation that may exist amongst women? You could endlessly categorise and endlessly quota. Yet again, I’m afraid, this is more European EU interference. Companies should have the freedom to choose the most suitable candidate for a job, but under Article 6 and Recital 30 of this Directive, there are calls for sanctions, for fines to be imposed and forced dissolution of companies that do not fulfil the quota requirements. Quotas do not address nor resolve underlying issues of inequality. They are truly counter—productive. (Applause)

name: Stanisław ŻÓŁTEK
text: On behalf of the ENF Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I see that this feminist madness continues, we want to turn women into men and men into women. I don't really understand if it's a disease or something else, but while it was so ridiculous (like the last vote that there are not enough women grazing sheep and goats), you could only laugh at it. But such a directive, which in companies will introduce the principle that competence does not count, and the amount of how many women there are, how many men, is already dangerous. One could, of course, be mocked that what a problem it is, a few guys will say that they are women, and gender balance will be preserved. You voted for it yourself, and now you have done the right thing. But this thing is too serious to stop. We see that all the important law in the European Union is created by the European Commission, and Parliament obediently sticks to it, although sometimes it is unfortunately the initiator of more than nonsensical and harmful rights because of a group of Members. These rights, piece by piece, take away personal freedom, take away economic freedom from entrepreneurs, take away independence from states. These resolutions, which the European Parliament here creates in the thousands – usually nonsensical or unspealing – have one common denominator: it must be concluded that immigrants, homosexuals and, of course, feminist movements are better than European citizens. It must be contained, it is really some kind of disease. It is high time we left this Union, i.e. it is impossible to reform it. Here I appeal to other countries: in the footsteps of the United Kingdom, leave this Union, to the Members, to prepare it. Let us create a new union, as was the case in the dreams of the founders of this, unfortunately, present one. Let it be a union just as borderless, but one that does not interfere with families does not ridicule women raising children by saying that they are domestic chickens, as I have heard here recently. One that does not interfere with the economy. Where the European Commission is obedient officials, not all of us. Such a union needs to be re-established, there is no other way out. I hope that I will live to this time, because in two years' time it will no longer be possible to leave this Union, this is the last moment.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Let me try to explain something to you. Please focus, I only have a minute. You come out of false assumptions and come to false conclusions as a result. Firstly, you assume at the outset that women have the same predisposition, qualifications and the same desire to take management positions as men. From a false premise, you go on to lament that there is an imbalance in the boards. You air on this conspiracy theory, some sort of patriarchal conspiracy that prevents women from being promoted to company boards. The preliminary premise is verified by reality, by the economy: if women are not employed as willingly, or do not push themselves to the boards, they apparently either do not have the same competences, the same predispositions, or the same desire to follow such a path. Men, for example, are occupying it because they live shorter lives. How are you going to repair the losses of men, level the case in this aspect? If the market shows that women don't occupy as many of the same positions, then apparently the cause is elsewhere, not in the men's conspiracy.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, we live in a time and in a society where no one doubts gender equality, yet we see that the representation of women in important places does not correspond to the fact that they make up one half of the population. Indeed, the representation of women on the governing and supervisory bodies of large listed companies is surprisingly low. The European average is 23%, and in some countries, such as the Czech Republic, it is only 9%. Although women achieve the same education, even today more than half of university graduates are women, they certainly have the same ambitions, they are equally capable, so women are still absent from these crucial bodies. This is also due to the fact that women have an irreplaceable role as mothers and carers. They enter their professional careers later. No quota alone will allow women to speed up their careers. It will help women to improve their conditions to be mothers while developing their professional careers. I see it as very important here that, on the contrary, the Council should look at the adoption of a directive to bring parental and professional life into order to reach a consensus here that this directive should be applied by the Member States. I would like to ask my colleagues here, who are calling for the directive to be approved, what is preventing their Member States from taking this measure? For example, my colleagues in Spain say, 'Approve the directive', after all, Spain has already unblocked negotiations in the Council. Well, colleague, it is not a problem for your progressive government to adopt such regulation in its remit. I think that nothing prevents this at Member State level. I would like to call on the European Commission and public administrations to lead by example and support women in senior positions.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Over 65% of university graduates in the EU are women. They have the knowledge, they have the experience of the top jobs on the company boards. Yet they continue to be marginalised from influence. That is totally unacceptable! But it's not only unfair, it's stupid too. It's a waste of competence. The probability of innovation in equal enterprises is almost twice as high. Moreover, it has long been demonstrated that the more women among the top managers of listed companies, the better the conditions for financial performance that benefit companies. Nevertheless, many Member States and right-wing politicians continue to consistently oppose the proposal that at least 40% of non-executive directors should be of the under-represented sex. It's a very strange policy.  It is therefore with great pleasure that we have noted that Spain is now changing its mind and withdrawing its reservation in the Council of Ministers. That is why Romania should take this seriously and not just have fine words, but should act to ensure that we have fair and better opportunities for innovation in Europe.

name: Czesław HOC
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by On the issue of women on company boards and gender balance in general, let us look at the three most important institutions of the European Union: the European Parliament, the European Commission and the European Council. Out of the 12 presidents of the European Commission so far, not a single woman. Next, out of the 30 Presidents of the European Parliament – only two ladies and 78 (78!) Presidents of the European Council – only two women. Why, then, do women's organisations not show this fact in Parliament, why did no male President hit his chest? Is it necessary for this act of courage until an EU directive?  So everyone is equal before the law. Both men and women have equal rights in family, political, social and economic life – this is enshrined in the Constitution of the Republic of Poland. We are a society of resourceful, educated, competent and responsible women. Everyone needs respect and fair treatment, for he has identical rights and equal dignity. This should simply be observed, that is our modern axiological and civilizational imperative.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Mr President, thank you, Mrs Jourová, always for your support, for your strength and for your determination. Today, some still say that women do not hold leadership positions because they choose not to. And yet the proportion of women on the board of directors of listed European companies has increased from 10% in 2005 to 22% in 2015. Then something moves.  Others say that, if things are already changing, an initiative like the proposal on women on board would be unnecessary. However, women only chair 7% of the board of directors and are only 6% of the CEOs of the largest companies. The glass ceiling exists. The sticky floor exists. And, from the European Union, we can help break one and clean up another. But to do so, it is necessary for the Council to stop blocking the proposal on women on the board of directors. Equality in leadership positions is positive for all. Companies with more women on board get better results. The rational, the effective, the pragmatic with principles is equality. It is time for the Council to unlock the proposal on women on the board of directors and assume the leadership that Europeans are asking for. And I expect a good position on Romania.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my colleagues from the Group of the Party of European Liberal, Public Health and Consumer Policy and the Group of the Greens for tab forward these two oral questions. With the report on gender mainstreaming, for which Mrs Mlinar was rapporteur, we have worked in the same direction. Clearly we must be aware that we are taking action on a symptom of a discriminatory culture and we are working with positive action to prevent these data that emerge once again from the studies carried out from becoming a vector of further discrimination.  However, we must be aware that this Parliament must provide answers, not only for that glass ceiling which affects 1% of women, but for those forms of discrimination and violence which affect 99% of women; it must combat all forms of discrimination of gender, class or race, and I believe that this European Parliament can make a contribution in this direction.  I would really like to thank my fellow Members for these oral questions. I truly believe, however, that we have a great deal to do in a parliamentary term which, as Mr Urtasun said, could have done more from the point of view of gender equality.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as far back as November 2012, Parliament voted at first reading on the proposal for a directive on women on boards of directors, which is still blocked in the Council.  This proposal for a directive was born with the aim of bringing greater equality between women and men to the boards of the largest listed companies on the stock exchange, although we are aware that there will only be real equality when it can be achieved thanks to the merit shown on the ground and not thanks to a gender quota imposed a priori, merit and skills that we women have – and I would like to reassure the member who spoke earlier – I am sorry for him but it is data show that more women graduates than their male colleagues.  The starting points with which the Commission had proposed this directive were worrying: only 13.7% of the posts were occupied by women. Today, therefore, I wonder and ask the Romanian Presidency: what measures does it intend to take to finally break this deadlock? I also wonder whether you will be able to respond to the demands of European women, which we represent here, in the Council.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, it is well known that men disproportionately make up the numbers of corporate boards across the world. According to the European Institute for Gender Equality, in 2017, women accounted for only a quarter of all board members in the largest publicly listed companies registered in the EU. In fact, in 2015, there were more CEOs of Fortune 500 companies named John than there were women. Nothing wrong with John – my own name is Seán, which is the Gaelic form of John. This proposed directive is not simply about making up a gender balance on corporate boards of directors and non—executive directors; it’s about the trickle—down effect this has on the entire company and the economy. One will often find women working in the human resources or communication side of a company, while men are more often in general management as this is seen as more senior. There must be a gender—balanced model of decision making at all levels within the company concerned. If people running the company are primarily comprised of men, how can we expect the company as a whole to represent the whole spectrum of opinions and perspectives? Furthermore, inadequate recruitment practices for board members contribute to perpetually hiring those with similar profiles, i.e., we as humans tend to hire who we are familiar with, so if the board is comprised primarily of men, this leads to more men being hired. This does not make sense. According to the International Monetary Fund, women’s economic empowerment boosts productivity, and increases economic diversification and income equality. It makes absolute sense to have more women on boards.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in our debates we often remember that gender equality is a founding value of the European Union, even if we are then oriented differently in behaviour, as this morning's debate shows. What the Council is doing is simply shameful: we are dealing with a directive voted on by a very large majority now more than 7 years ago and nothing is happening.  It is not an extraordinary objective that contained in the directive: the presence of women on the boards of directors of 40% does not have the same share in top positions, for example: it has remained open and the question of the difference in pay, for the same work, between men and women will remain open for a long time to come.  Therefore, what we had decided was a small step in the right direction, but one that was simply a good intention. I hope that the Council will want – and demonstrate its practical desire to do so – to move in the right direction, which is to respect and also to give legs to the directive we have voted on.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Mr President, 'In a society without equality, really, what harmony and beauty can prevail?', John Milton wondered. I wonder the same thing. The glass ceiling that hinders the careers of thousands of working women is upsetting their lives. Workers with experience, studies and training are excluded from managerial positions, are paid less, are 'punished', if they have or want a family, they are harassed in various forms. The proposal for a directive is certainly another opportunity to correct inequalities that prevail. But why is it taking so long to adopt?  I ask the Council: What initiatives will it take to tackle the glass ceiling phenomenon in businesses? How does it intend to promote gender equality during the Romanian Presidency?

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in 2017, it was said, women made up only a quarter of the boards of directors of the largest Listed European companies and, even today, the approaches adopted by the Member States in this area vary considerably, resulting in obvious inequalities within the Union.  Insufficient use of the skills of highly qualified women is not only unacceptable discrimination based on gender stereotypes, but also detrimental to the optimal functioning of the labour market in the Union. In order to achieve better gender equality, it has been shown that significant progress can be made through the adoption of legislative measures providing for so-called 'pink quotas'.  In fact, in my country, Italy, for example, with the introduction of a specific law on the subject, in just five years, 33% of women's presence on boards has been exceeded, which has had a positive effect on all performance indicators, precisely thanks to the competence of women.  We therefore call on the Romanian Presidency to define as soon as possible the negotiations on the proposal for a directive on gender balance in the management boards.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, honourable members of the Council, Commissioner, a subject debated, as colleagues have said, for seven years. I want to tell you this, especially for the men who have raised the issue of inequality here and for the men at home who feel complex: anthropologically, women are designed to be good! Good in business and at home, women always have two jobs, at least two jobs. And as a woman who was on the board and at state-owned companies, and at her own companies, I say very clearly: women can carry this task. There are no professions for men and women, and I hope, Minister, Commissioner, that we will eliminate this democracy upside down, this minority in the Council which has been blocking a very good thing for so many years. I hate that we have to have a quota, but if society has not understood to take advantage of the female value in society, I think we need to intervene, because yes, I agree, Commissioner, the directive on the balance between private and family life, and what you have said, that there are relevant studies, must be put into practice. We will all benefit, the whole society!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the under-representation of women in society and in key positions and in the economy is a social phenomenon and obviously this needs to change and of course women should also be represented on business boards. But social engineering, the 'social engineering' that the European Union is trying to achieve, I do not think it can succeed in this area, nor can businesses be forced to do anything different.  But the European Union can do something else and, because Mr Juncker is here listening, I say this: EUR 140 billion a year is the budget of the European Union. EUR 70 billion is the funds of the European Investment Bank. Mr Draghi has given EUR 2.5 trillion. I therefore say that there should be no financing from Community funds or loans or the purchase of bonds from the European Central Bank if these companies do not have representation of women on the boards. See how businesses will immediately be forced to change tactics and have representation of women on boards, because they will have no access to either the economy, bonds or, of course, the money that is also from the Juncker programme. In this way we give an answer and make businesses come to what we want.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we note from the debate that has taken place this morning in this House that there is broad convergence in this Parliament on this directive which, mind you, is nothing extraordinary: it is a small step in the right direction, because the presence of women on the boards is not being imposed here; it is simply being noted that not only 50 % of the male universe can be represented on boards, but that women's representation is also called for.  So where's the problem? The problem is, as usual, within the Council. I say this with great regret and with great concern because, on the one hand, there is an attitude on the part of Parliament which would like to enable these institutions and the European Union to make progress. On the other hand, there is the Council's attitude, which all too often, Mr President, blocks actions that go in the right direction.  So, if it is true that equality is a fundamental principle of the European Union, action must be taken!

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am pleased with this directive and I am pleased with the debate, for a number of reasons. I think it is very good that more and more men are also involved when we talk about it, because we must do this together as a society, to achieve greater equality for women and more representation of women in all areas, because they are really good enough, just as good as men. The gender pay gap has been raised. I know that it is particularly high in Germany, higher than in other countries. We are currently discussing a parity law with very different approaches. Some Member States already have an equality law for the under-represented sex. I think it is actually a disgrace that we still have to talk about it; it would be good if we already had it.  I was very pleased, for example, with Mrs Regner, who said that it is actually in European DNA that there is equality between men and women. That is why I hope for broad support for this. We just really have to see that we finally get to a conclusion.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, it is astonishing to see that this initiative to push for gender balance on the boards of businesses remains blocked in the Council after more than five years. It truly shows how conservative the Member State governments can be. It is worrying that this initiative is so controversial. Pushing for equality at executive level in companies is a policy that, while important, still remains focused largely on privileged women. It’s no wonder we have so much trouble, then, highlighting the narratives of marginalised women. In the business world, women who find themselves at the intersection of several forms of discrimination face incredible challenges: black, Roma, migrant, disabled or poor women are too often forgotten in political spheres, as well as in the world of work and business. Following the agreement reached last week on the Work-Life Balance Directive, I call on the Presidency to put an end to this shameful situation, and focus all its efforts towards finally finding a consensus with regard to women on boards.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, gender equality for the Council is secondary, just see a picture of the European Council. Women on boards, for example in Spain, only occupy 22% of the positions in listed companies. In Sweden alone it reaches 36%, but in general far from the levels that Europe says. In the last parliamentary term, as a member of the Committee on Gender Equality, we discussed this and it is sad to see that, seven years later, we are here again on an area which is the pure picture of non-compliance with the equality directives.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Mr President, first of all, as a Romanian MEP, I welcome the fact that the Women on Boards directive proposal is one of the priorities of the Romanian Presidency in advancing gender equality. With some Member States changing their position recently, I am confident and I count on the Council to push forward the negotiation. The reasons for the under-representation of women in business leadership are complex and include prevalent political and corporate cultures and traditional gender stereotypes. The glass ceiling in the business culture not only devalues the contribution of female leadership but also discourages other women from fully developing their potential in professional careers. From my own experience I can tell you that women taking the leadership in the company makes for added value and enterprise growth, prioritising women’s needs in shaping the enterprise culture. Therefore, I express my support for the Romanian Presidency continuing the discussion on this directive.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am really grateful for the determination, dedication and support of the European Parliament for this course, which has been obvious through the whole debate. I am also grateful for the interest of the media in this topic. Let me conclude by saying a few words. Next to the clear support which I have already expressed from the Commission side for this piece of legislation, I wanted to tell you that we are not waiting for this to be unblocked in the Council because there is still a lot of work which can be done to support higher or better diversity, and not only in in the world of business.  I would like to mention again several statistics. In our society more than 50% are women. We have 62% of university graduates who are women. So one would say that it would be normal if we had at least such an adequate position and representation of women in various spheres of life, but let’s just compare these figures. We have 22% of women on boards. We have only 6% of chief executives. Coming a little bit further, to the political sphere, we have only 20% of women in national parliaments. We have some governments in the Member States where there are only one or two women. Recently there was one government where there were no women.  Let’s come to a positive example now. I am happy to say that in the Commission we are already tackling the 40% in managerial positions, which is thanks to the continuous strong push and very smart procedure which is guaranteeing fair competition, free of any kind of bias or barriers which we see in many other places. To react to what Mr Żółtek said here – he is no longer here – believe me, from my position as a woman in the Commission, I still feel very strongly as a woman that I didn’t have to become a man to be in such a position and to contribute to the decision—making of the Commission. It’s a coincidence that Jean—Claude Juncker is here, but he said very clearly ‘at least nine women for the Commission’ and I think that all my women colleagues are doing the right job by bringing the perspective of women into decision—making. So when we compare those figures, we have to say that there is something unhealthy and abnormal in other European societies, and that’s why we are working hard to change this. As I said, we are not only waiting for the unblocking of the directive on women on boards. By the way, I would like to ask Ms Parker to read the current version of the directive because you will not find anything there which would indicate that gender itself – to be a woman only – is the qualification. We are inviting fair competition and cooperation. It’s good to pay attention to the current version, which we are promoting.  At this moment, half of the Member States already have the legislation so, if we move on with the legislation, we will help the remaining Member States. It’s true that the Member States can act themselves. They do not have to wait for the unblocking of this directive because it’s up to them to move on this. In the meantime, the Commission is not waiting. We are doing a lot of non—legislative work. We are supporting the Diversity Charter, where there are now already 10 000 institutions, including the biggest companies. I will name a few of them: Sodexo, IKEA, IBM, Siemens. These are the multinationals which are promoting the idea of diversity, which is advantageous for business in many Member States, including the states where there is no legislation. So in fact they are exporting and spreading this positive corporate culture. We are also funding a lot of projects which promote diversity. So we are doing a lot of things in the meantime. It’s something which I call Plan B – not to wait for the adoption of the legislation, but to do a lot of other things. But I have to repeat at the end of my concluding remarks that we still believe that this piece of legislation will be adopted. Again I want to repeat that we trust the Romanian Presidency, that they will do a great job on this.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for this discussion. As I said in my opening remarks, the Council commitment to gender equality is real and unwavering. The Romanian Presidency has been organising bilateral talks with the blocking minority in order to seek a possible solution. We have also scheduled meetings at working—party level on the file, but we must not forget that the Presidency is in the hands of the Member States. Under the ordinary legislative procedure, an agreement among Member States requires a qualified majority.  In addition to the work we have undertaken in cooperation with Parliament to advance European legislation, we are also – as I mentioned – preparing a set of conclusions on the gender pay gap and policies to improve the reconciliation of work, family and private life. We hope to see these conclusions adopted at the Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs (EPSCO) Council on 13 June.  Allow me, also, to take this opportunity to inform you that the Romanian Presidency will be hosting the High—Level Group on Gender Mainstreaming in Bucharest in February. We are also looking forward to discussing the topic of gender equality at the informal meeting of the EPSCO ministers in Bucharest in April.  Thank you very much for this opportunity to discuss these important topics here today. By working together, the Council and Parliament, we can end discrimination and unfairness and make equal treatment a reality for all women and men. At this time of turbulence and transition, we face many challenges; however, the future belongs to equality.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The joint debate is closed. The next item is the debate with the Finnish Prime Minister, Juha Sipilä, on the future of Europe. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments) Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – Already in 2013, we have adopted our position in the European Parliament on this directive, which could serve as a very good example of ensuring gender equality in other areas. Gender equality in the highest positions of companies is still not guaranteed at European Union level, but the available talent should be exploited while promoting gender balance on the boards of all companies operating in the internal market. It is to be welcomed that the Spanish Government informed the Austrian Presidency a few months ago that it would withdraw its reservations on the proposal and proposed to actively cooperate with EU partners to reach a sufficient majority for the agreement. I therefore call on the Romanian Presidency currently to include the issue of the Women's Boards Directive on the agenda of Council meetings in order to find a way out of this impasse, which this directive has come to the end of the current parliamentary term. It is essential to ensure that gender equality becomes a key topic of EU debate again.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – While gender equality is one of the fundamental values of the European Union, women continue to be a strong minority on the boards and supervisory boards of companies, despite continued efforts to increase gender diversity in key national bodies. Today, globally, women hold 15% of board seats. In Poland, similarly, women hold a little more than 15% of the supervisory board share and are at the head of 6.3% of the boards of companies among the more than 480 listed companies on the main market.  In the European Union, the introduction of quota rules in some Member States has been a success. However, data collected by the European Institute for Equality between Women and Men shows that in 2017, women accounted for only 25% of all board members of the largest listed companies registered in the EU, with large disparities between Member States, where the share of women ranged from 7.4% to 43%. This clearly demonstrates the importance of the EU directive.  That is why the Council's attitude on this issue is so deeply worrying. Although the European Parliament adopted its position as early as 2013, when it supported the Commission's initiative to tackle inequality by requiring at least 40% of women to participate on company boards, the directive is still blocked in the Council despite numerous calls from us.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. – Unfortunately, for years we have been talking about legislation at European level that ensures gender balance in the management of companies, but things are not moving. In 2012, the Commission published a proposal for a directive on improving the balance between men and women among non-executive directors of publicly traded enterprises, commonly known as the 'Directive on Women on Boards'. Under the proposal, the level of at least 40% of non-executive members of underrepresented sex on corporate boards should be reached by 2020 in the private sector and by 2018 in the public sector (the so-called 'procedural quota'). Despite pressure from the Commission and the Council, the situation is not moving forward at all. It is necessary that, before the end of this mandate, the Romanian Presidency should take all necessary measures to reach an agreement between the Member States and the adoption of the Directive.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Gender equality is a fundamental value of the European Union, so women must enjoy the same opportunities as men in order to take managerial positions, both in the economic and financial and transport sectors. The added and entrepreneurial economic value that women actively bring in high-responsibility positions is well known. The Commission's 2012 proposal on the Directive on Women's Participation on Boards sought to mitigate inequalities by requiring a minimum representation of 40% of women on company boards. Although Parliament has adopted and supported the Commission's initiative since 2013, the directive is still blocked in the Council. The introduction of legislation on the representation of at least 40% of women on boards has proved to be a success only in some states. Statistically, women still account for only a quarter of all board members, with large discrepancies between Member States, where the presence of women on boards ranges from 7% to 43%. This clearly shows that we need a European directive to balance the share of women in executive positions in any field of activity.

name: Monika VANA
text: Writing. We need a women's offensive in Europe. Both the EU Member States and the Commission have banned women's policy into the darkroom. There are many easy-to-implement measures at the table to ensure greater equality quickly. It is a disgrace that the governments of the EU states have still not given their consent to this! The European Parliament has already done its homework. It is incomprehensible that the proportion of women in listed companies in Austria fell from 6 to 4.8% in 2018. Out of 186 board members, only nine are female. Now it is the turn of the Member States to finally implement gender mainstreaming seriously. It is obvious that where measures have been taken, there has also been a change. However, there must also be serious sanctions for companies if they do not meet the quota.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: First of all, I want to thank the Finnish Prime Minister for being here. Thank you very much. it is important for us to hear the different positions of the different countries on the future of the European Union. For the European Parliament there are two, three or four key points. We want more power for the European Parliament. We want more Europe and not less Europe. We want to strengthen Europe and not to destroy Europe. On the MFF, we are in favour of a change from 1.1 to 1.3. We are in favour of own resources. Immigration is also an important point for the European Parliament. The European Parliament approved the reform of the Dublin rules. We want a decision by the European Council on this. At the centre of today’s debate there are two key points: Brexit and Venezuela. It is important to know your ideas on the future of the European Union. We know the position of the European Commission. There is the position of the European Parliament of course and there are the positions of different Member States. Now it is important to know the position of Finland. Prime Minister, you have the floor.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Prime Minister of Finland. – Mr President, I bring warm regards from very cold Finland. I was in the northern part of Finland, where I live, last weekend, and there was minus 30° and about a metre of snow – a real winter! It’s a pleasure to be here today. The European Parliament has done excellent work in the recent very challenging circumstances. Forward-looking discussions about the European Union are essential for two reasons. In order to realise the vision of the Rome Declaration we need to discuss how we achieve sufficient unity to make decisions and implement them. Secondly, we must debate to discover each other’s priorities in relation to the EU’s action and budget. EU countries became familiar to me as an entrepreneur through sister companies around Europe. I remember, in my thirties, travelling to meet the CEO of a big French company. On the plane, I read a guidebook my wife had borrowed from the library for me. It said that you should never ask anything about family when you are in a business meeting with a Frenchman. When I arrived, there was a dinner meeting and the CEO was there with wife and daughter. The first question to me was ‘Tell me about your family.’ So I understood that we Europeans get along and we have more in common than we may think.  As long ago as the 1920s, a founder of the Finnish Centre Party, Santeri Alkio, wrote that, for the sake of peace in Europe, the continent should consider shifting its politics towards a United States of Europe. He even mentioned a common currency. He was a pioneer in many respects, including this one. Choosing international cooperation and generating peace and economic development have been guiding threads for Finland. Friends, in recent years we have been given a lesson in populism in Europe. We have seen where it leads to when the solutions for complex issues are provided by simplifying matters. In the end, nobody takes responsibility. There has been such a case in the United Kingdom and the result is there for all to see. Not only Brexit but also populism hit the EU from several fronts. Setbacks on the rule of law, freedom of the press and women’s rights are news we would not expect to hear in 21st century Europe. How can the EU promote its common values in its external policies if it can’t do so within the Union? Common values such as democracy and the rule of law have been the foundation of Europe’s freedom, security and prosperity. They should unite the Member States. It is essential to bridge Europeans’ internal divisions. At the same time, there cannot be any compromise on the rule of law. Finland warmly welcomes the Commission’s rule-of-law proposal in respect of the Multi-Annual Financial Framework (MFF). I am convinced that there is a way to establish a well-balanced mechanism to that end. Mr President, honourable Members, the cornerstone in terms of Finland’s position towards a developing EU, as well as monetary union, is to respect what has been agreed and to ensure efficient implementation. We strongly support the kind of European Union that achieves its credibility throughout concrete action. In 2015, my Government started with a situation where our public deficit was nearly 3.5% relative to GDP. We made 2% painful savings. We implemented reforms, improving public finances, including social and healthcare reform and pension reform. An internal devaluation of 4% was made for the purpose of boosting employment and growth. We agreed with the unions on a salary freeze and cuts, an extension of 24 hours in annual working time and a decrease in employees’ social security contributions, to name but a few aspects. As you might guess, this list was not very popular. However, now, after three years, the public deficit is covered, the state budget is in balance and the employment rate is the highest in 30 years. With that said, the idea of solving problems of this kind through permanent fiscal transfers is unacceptable for us. The best insurance against economic shocks is a balanced budget and a low debt ratio. Many times over these years, I have come back to a quote from Jean Claude Juncker – ‘We all know what to do, we just don’t know how to get re-elected after we have done it.’ For my part, I am testing this in practice in the upcoming elections in April. Let’s see! My point is that, despite the risk, the Member States must be capable of making decisions and implementing them. Efficient implementation is absolutely the best method of responding to current and future challenges. We need implementation of the single market and R&D and innovations, implementation of the internal and external security policies, implementation of migration policies, implementation of climate policies. Better implementation is the best tool in fighting populism and in increasing citizens’ confidence in the European Union. Honourable Members, Finland holds the EU Presidency in the second half of this year, so next I will point out some areas that will be on the agenda during our Presidency. These are also topics on which the EU must be able to work more closely together and to ‘walk the talk’ efficiently. I’ll start with the MFF, which is a key implementation tool for future EU policy. In Finland’s view, the overall level of the MFF should be as close as possible to current relative share. The focus needs to be in the areas where the EU is best placed to deliver, such as migration, security, the single market, innovation, digitalisation and climate. We also see a need to reallocate funding for rural development within the budget. The common agriculture policy helps to provide affordable and safe food to our citizens. It ensures that farmers can make a reasonable living and it promotes jobs in the farming and food industry. At the same time, cohesion policy creates more balanced development between and inside the Member States. I am confident that we will be able to find a balanced compromise between traditional policy areas and new challenges. I am also confident that we can do it during the Finnish Presidency. Secondly, we need a migration policy with a comprehensive approach. To begin with, the root causes of migration must be addressed more efficiently. In addition to development cooperation and humanitarian aid, trade and investments are needed to create jobs and sustainable development. We must also work hard to develop a more effective return policy. The internal aspect of migration is in our own hands. We should manage migration increasingly throughout direct resettlements from the refugee camps. This would mean less pressure on the EU’s external borders and less smuggling. At the same time, management of our external borders should be reinforced. There is also a need to proceed with the most complicated political issues, including a mechanism on solidarity during crises. It’s crucial that we agree on this in advance, not in the middle of a crisis – as we did in 2015. Thirdly, security and defence cooperation is important and needs to be intensified. Finland has been actively calling for ambitious progress on security and defence cooperation, together too with France. Now we welcome the progress made: the creation of a European defence fund and Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) have been steps in the right direction. Now we should take concrete action on implementation and achieving results.  The EU has also strengthened its capacity for countering hybrid threats. The European Centre for Countering Hybrid Threats, in Helsinki, contributes to the preparedness of NATO and EU countries against these threats. I want to thank the 19 participating countries, of which 16 are EU Member States, for their strong commitment. I would also welcome all the remaining Member States joining the centre. Fourth, we must improve the single market. We are the best single market in the world. Alongside innovation and trade, this is our best way to create new jobs. A lot of potential exists, especially in services and digital products. Improving the situation is entirely in our own hands. I urge you to find a common mindset in order to pass those 35 proposals which are still under negotiation.  Looking ahead, I hope that the future Commission will take a more holistic approach, within which the single market, digitalisation, industrial policy and external competitiveness are better interlinked. We should aim at forward-looking growth strategy, including, inter alia, data mobility and artificial intelligence. It’s also important to enhance competitiveness by implementing the principles of the EU social pillar. For instance, it is crucial to promote equality in working life and to enhance the education level of all citizens. Fifth, trade policy is also crucial for the EU’s competitiveness and new jobs. In respect of free trade agreements, I am pleased with the latest achievements vis-à-vis Japan, Vietnam, Singapore, Mexico and Canada, and with the rapid progress in ongoing negotiations. However, it’s harmful if the big players continue to build trade walls. We must do everything we can to prevent the erection of, or tear down, such walls. This is especially the view from smaller countries, to which the damage would be fatal. We must respect and obey the common rules on trade. And lastly, the EU must take a lead on climate change action. The report by the International Panel on Climate Change again reminded us of the threat posed by climate change to life on Earth. We can’t walk away from science. Besides a threat, I see many possibilities in this global challenge. As an engineer, I tend to think in a solution-based and technology-based way. I am sure that, as the world moves towards low-carbon development, we are in the front line in developing new technologies, and ambitious climate policy will also support job creation here in Europe. We need measures on three fronts: CO2 emissions, carbon sinks and new technologies. Last week, Finland hosted a Nordic climate meeting in Helsinki. Nordic countries gave a promise to raise the level of their climate ambition by 2020. The Nordic countries want to catalyse mitigation efforts to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees. Also in the round-table discussions in the Finnish Parliament, eight Finnish parties set an objective that the EU should achieve carbon neutrality before 2050. That requires tightening the emission reduction obligation for 2030 to at least 55% of the 1990 levels. The EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) is the most cost-efficient way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Finland aims to renew the system so that the price of the emission allowances guides operators towards emission reductions more quickly and efficiently. We have proposed that new sectors, such as heating and cooling of buildings, be integrated into the ETS. Furthermore, we have accelerated the transition towards a circular economy and the bio-economy. The Bio-economy Action Plan should be implemented without delay. As a small detail, my Government decided not to give any EU Presidency gifts: instead we used the money to offset the emissions caused by air travel during the Presidency. (Applause) Second, we need to increase carbon sinks. We have four billion hectares of forest and five billion hectares of fields. It has surprised me to learn how much more agricultural fields could bind CO2 if we made some changes in farming practices. We have 100 so-called carbon farmers testing new practices in Finland. Oceans and carbonate minerals too can lock down carbon dioxide, and we also need to plant more forests. In Africa alone, two million hectares of forest are lost every year. That is equivalent to Slovenia’s total land area. As the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation’s report on the state of the world’s forests says, the world response to climate change must focus more on forest. One concrete step we should take in relation to the EU’s external funding is to increase global carbon sinks. Finland has proposed an EU-African forest fund. Forest investments would maximise the impact on climate and rural jobs in Africa. Third, new technology must be adapted. Even now, we have the technical capacity to capture CO2 from the air and convert it into other products. The EU needs to invest in research and development and to exploit the huge potential of science, technology and innovation in this area more effectively. We also have to think of innovative ways – new incentives and market driven methods – to ensure carbon sinks will be increased. My strong message is that we have to do more and faster. We must reduce emissions, increase carbon sinks and adapt new technologies to capture CO2 from the air or directly from the emission sources. Fellow Europeans, after the European Parliament elections, the European Council needs to agree on an ambitious and comprehensive agenda. Besides climate change, our focus should be on growth and security, while rule-of-law issues will also remain central. This is my call for a more united European Union, capable of concrete action and implementation, and of bearing responsibility. This means responsibility for ourselves, for people and their surroundings close to us, for the economy and for the planet. Let’s remember that we are all here to safeguard a better future for youth and the generations to come. For our sake and for our common future, we all need a determined, efficient and united European Union. I cannot highlight more the importance of getting things done. That is why I have underlined the word ‘implementation’ in this speech so many times. The democratic forces of Europe will win back the trust of the people by making decisions and implementing them, at home and also here in Brussels. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: président de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président, Monsieur le Premier ministre, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, nous sommes heureux, Jyrki et moi, d'étre avec le Premier ministre finlandais, mon ami Juha. La Finlande est devenue membre de l'Union européenne en 1995. Le hasard a voulu que je sois devenu Premier ministre le m me jour, et depuis lors, l'Europe fonctionne parfois. J'ai toujours noté que la Finlande, d's le premier jour de son adhésion, se comportait comme un état membre fondateur, comme si elle avait toujours été l, et certains états membres fondateurs gagneraient prendre exemple sur elle et (Applaudissements) La Finlande, depuis qu'elle est membre, a toujours fait preuve d'une grande faculté d'écoute. La Finlande et ses gouvernements respectifs savent écouter, et la Finlande entend ce qu'elle écoute et traduit en politiques ce qu'elle a appris en écoutant les autres. Tel fut le cas de tous les Premiers ministres. J'ai commencé avec Paavo Lipponen, j'étais avec mon ami Jyrki, je suis avec toi maintenant, et je verrai Paavo ce soir. Aujourd'hui, j'ai une journée finlandaise. Trois Premiers ministres qui s'adressent a la Commission, c'est rare, mais c'est utile. La troisi me présidence finlandaise point l'horizon, et ce sera une présidence particuli re puisqu'elle interviendra apr s les élections européennes, avant la nomination de nouveaux présidents de la Commission et du Conseil, avant la nomination du président de la Banque centrale, et ce sera donc une période qui demandera beaucoup de doigté, lorsqu'il s'agit de présider l'Union européenne, comme la Finlande l'a fait lors de ses deux premi' When it comes to relations between Finland and the Commission, the relations couldn't be better. We are working in full confidence. That was the case when we were establishing the security and defense mechanism. That is the case when it comes to energy and climate, and this is the case when it comes to developing connectivity infrastructure in the border region of Finland.  I would, in the name of the Commission, like to make use of the Finnish Presidency in order to develop the Arctic dimension. This is an important issue because the Arctic region is warming at twice the global average rate of temperature increase. Finland is holding, for the time being, the Presidency of the Arctic Council. I was discussing with my friend Juha when I was in Finland in November the idea of calling during the Finnish Presidency a Summit of the Arctic Council because I think that we have to make sure that the Arctic region is moving to the top of the European agenda.  But the Finnish Presidency must also do a great deal. I would like – and I would like this – to make progress during the Finnish Presidency on deepening the Economic and Monetary Union, to complete the Banking Union and to put the Capital Markets Union on a definitive path. At the heart of what will happen under the Finnish Presidency, of course, is medium-term financial planning. That's a hard piece of work, that's drilling thick boards. And the Finnish Presidency can fully rely on the Commission to make the progress it needs during the Finnish Presidency to conclude at the European Council in October this year. We need to finalise this medium-term financial framework this year. Otherwise, we will lose the valuable time we need to design, develop and implement the programmes. I would also be grateful to the Finnish Presidency if, within the framework of the multiannual financial framework, but also in terms of deepening economic and monetary union, it kept on the table the Commission's proposals, which are: an instrument for strengthening structural reforms and a stabilisation instrument to make the European Economic and Monetary Union weatherproof against external shocks. The last European Council approached this issue cautiously like a hedgehog. But people are waiting for us to equip the Economic and Monetary Union in such a way that it can respond better to the next crisis than it did in the last crisis.
