And then I would also like to thank the Finnish Government for being one of those who have paid the greatest attention in Europe to the Jyrki investment plan and to me. So far, EUR 8 billion of investment has been implemented in Finland as a result of this plan. It would be good if everyone did so. I wish you, Juha, all the best in April, all the best for the Finnish Presidency. Keep it up! (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome Prime Minister Sipilä to the European Parliament. Prime Minister, you are here at a crucial moment in time. The people have the say for the future of your country in April, and Europe in May, so it is a democratic competition in the next weeks ahead of us.  I start with this because your capital, Helsinki, is for my party, for the European People’s Party (EPP), and also for myself, a special place of democracy. We had our Congress there when I was nominated as candidate for my party and practised there what people expect from us – to have competition, to have lively discussions about the future, to present candidates, and then people can choose. People decide about the future, in which direction we should go. The principles of nationalism and European democracy will be at the centre of developments in the upcoming months.  I want to share some points you mentioned in your speech; some considerations on this. First, from the EPP point of view, I fully support what you said on financial discipline. It sounds technical, it sounds market—orientated, it sounds euro—business orientated. But it is absolutely in the interests of our children. Sustainability is the key word when we talk about financial discipline, and the EU will always have the EPP on a national level, and on a European level with us as the EPP, and Jyrki is also working on this on your side. Then it is about this sustainability, because that means future.  The second point I want to mention is an answer to your speeches about the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). There, let me be a little bit critical because you started in your paragraph on speaking about the MFF, you started with saying first of all the amount of money must be fixed. That is what we always hear from the national leaders. I think that’s the wrong question. A good question is: what are the tasks ahead of us? What is the demand we have in the European Union? Because we hear from a lot of leaders that say we should fix the money but then additionally we need a strong border control, we have to do something on cybersecurity and we have to build up more innovation in the European Union. So if this is a demand for Europe, then the Member States must also be fair with the contribution to the budget. Then we have to put the money on the table we need for giving an answer on the demands on the table. So the starting point is to speak about the demands.  The third point I want to mention in my short contribution today is about, probably the most challenging for all of us, and is what 35 000 school kids told us when there was demonstrating in the last weeks in Europe – Pope Francis is calling it the illness of the earth – and that is climate change. Thank you for your statement on this specific point. I want to only underline the approach towards the climate change challenge, some of the principles we, as the EPP, believe in. One principle is that the solution on climate change, to give an answer is not to forbid things, is not to prohibit things, is not to ban things. It’s not to say to the citizen that they cannot go any more on their holidays to Majorca because the CO2 footprint is too intense. That’s not our answer. Our answer is that in the future people will fly to Majorca in a clean airplane. Innovation is the key to give an answer on this. That is what we have to do. We cannot say to the developing countries or to the emerging economies in the world that they have to stop to grow. That they cannot develop anymore. That is not the answer. The answer is that we as Europeans can provide the developing countries with the technologies to have growth without climate impact. That is our answer. So innovation is, for us, a key principle.  The second point I want to underline in the CO2 field is that we have to do it together with the people. The people must follow the changes. In the car industry we have a lot of people who are concerned about the changes. You see the demonstrations of the Yellow Vests in France, for example. A lot of people here in this room can finance higher energy prices, but outside there are a lot of people who cannot finance higher energy prices. So we have to do the changes in a way that people accept the changes and follow our approach. We have to create winners and not losers in this regard.  Finally on CO2 and climate change: together, we are strong. We made the Paris Agreement possible. We made the steps already with the CO2 car emission reduction for example. We are ambitious. We are the owner of this fight against CO2 on a global level and we can show to our citizens that together we can achieve a lot.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to the Prime Minister that his country, Finland, is among the world leaders in many areas from clean energy and gender equality to social progress. I think Transparency International only this week named Finland as the third least corrupt country in the world and let us not forget last year’s World Happiness Report, according to which Finns are now the happiest people in the world. Coming from Denmark I am a little bit disappointed that you took over our place at that point. Congratulations on this impressive record. Finland clearly demonstrates that small countries can be on top of the world, not only in geographical terms. But, Prime Minister, in your speech today, besides better implementation, I missed this ambition to be a champion and driver for positive social change in Europe. Where is your ambition to make Europe the world leader in a transformation to a sustainable development model in a just way where all people are included? Where is your ambition to make the lives of Europeans better? What you presented to us today sounded a little bit more like yesterday’s neoliberal slogans that led to the deep economic and social crisis in Europe. Prime Minister, we Socialists and Democrats have an ambitious vision for Europe. We live in times when our Earth and our sources of life are under attack from climate change and pollution. You rightly mentioned that. The air we breathe, the water we drink, the soil our crops are grown in are the future of our children and it is our duty to protect them. But our citizens and our workers are also tired of being the only ones paying for the transformation to a more sustainable way of production. They are outraged to see multinationals polluting our planet and reaping huge benefit, but not paying their fair taxes. This must change, Prime Minister. We need to change the Stability and Growth Pact to become a true sustainability pact for Europe. Therefore we have drawn up a plan to shift towards more sustainable ways of working, producing, living which go hand in hand with social progress for the people – a just transition – with the United Nations Development Goals as our signpost. Today I call on Finland to join us in this very important battle. We Europeans need to shape globalisation our way, not fall victim to destructive forces. We must be rule—makers, not rule—takers, because we live in times with growing inequality caused by the greediness of some elites and uncontrolled globalisation. The only way to address this is by finally fixing taxation and ensuring good salaries and working conditions for all, based on the Social Pillar. I didn’t hear you mention the Social Pillar some of us fought so hard to adopt in the European Union. Prime Minister, fair taxation is the foundation for European welfare states like the Nordic ones, which we come from, and citizens’ trust in democratic government. But are you willing to join us in this battle for fair taxation? Professor Richard Murphy showed in a study last week that the tax gap in Europe is EUR 825 billion, a gigantic amount of money. Our group has been in the forefront in the fight against money laundering and tax crimes. We call for a minimum corporate effective tax in Europe to stop the race to the bottom on corporate taxation. We call for stricter criteria and a for true tax haven list, which also calls out tax havens right here in the European Union. What do the people not understand is that while we as citizens have to pay high taxes, internet giants like Google and Facebook pay less than 1% in tax on what they earn in Europe? That is not fair. We need to protect our welfare states. We need to fight, not only for free, but also for fair, competition and for fairness for European citizens who today pay the price of multinationals’ tax dodging and we can achieve that. If we achieved that, Prime Minister, your recent project in Finland, – as I understand, the privatisation of hospitals and health care – could not just had been avoided, but public health care could have been strengthened in Finland, for example. So the status quo is not an option. It’s time for radical change to shape Europe for all people and leave nobody behind. Prime Minister, we see forces that are tearing our societies apart, but we need this radical change to social democracy and to more sustainable equality. We are campaigning for that as social democrats in Europe and we hope that liberals and other progressives will also join this fight. (Applause)

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Welcome to the European Parliament, Prime Minister Sipilä. Our common objective in the European Union must be to increase European prosperity. That is why I would now like to raise concrete issues, particularly immigration, the security of citizens, the prevention of tax evasion and the improvement of protection for whistleblowers. Prime Minister Sipilä, in autumn 2015 you publicly offered your unabashed nine-bedroom detached house to asylum seekers. News of this also spread to arab media, which further increased the number of people coming. Many young Iraqi men have said that the Prime Minister's offer prompted them to come specifically to Finland. In addition to the invitation made by the Prime Minister, those thinking about going to Europe were able to read descriptions of free education and medical services, clean and beautiful nature and beautiful young women with "blond hair, blue eyes and teeth like pearls" in the newspapers, quoting al-Arabia media. The Prime Minister's heartfelt invitation as such was an attraction factor, the adverse effects of which we are now facing in the form of high costs, as well as sexual offences against women and even children. In addition, the public's sense of security has deteriorated. Prime Minister Sipilä, do you recognise that, as a result of your generous offer, many people have come to Finland who have no grounds for asylum and who should never have been allowed into our country. The problems of the countries of origin will not be solved by relocating their populations to Europe, but must be solved at source. Europe's welfare states cannot function as a social agency for the whole world. There has been a lot of talk in Finland about the state of care for the elderly. Private companies providing housing and care services for the elderly have been particularly on the agenda. One of them has saved too much in personnel costs in its money-making process, while neglecting patient safety. Many companies have also avoided taxes through interest rate arrangements and by investing most of their holdings in tax haven islands. In addition to care for the elderly, the cases remind us that we need more effective means of combating tax evasion. It is good that the grievances that have been brewing under the surface for a long time come to light. It would be important to create a culture of action in which all crimes and infractions, such as serious neglect of care for the elderly, as well as tax evasion and environmental crimes, are dared to inform the supervisory authorities as soon as they are detected. Those who report abuses should not be punished, but should be seen as defenders of the public interest. Easy-to-use and confidential channels must be created for them to make notifications. I hope that effective protection of whistleblowers will be brought into legislation quickly in all EU countries, including Finland.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, well Prime Minister, as per Jean-Claude Juncker, my start as Prime Minister was also in Finland. You remember that my first Summit was in Tampere. I remember two things from Tampere in 1999: first of all, the reindeer on the menu for the Summit, and secondly that we decided there to have a common European migration and asylum policy. We are still struggling with the Member States to have one.  I am pleased that in your intervention, you started with Santeri Alkio who said – and I have a quote from him, it was Nils who helped me naturally, as he is from Finland – ‘the people’s idea of the League of Nations should be urgently taken by Europe to build a United States of Europe’. Whether it was in the 1920s or the 1930s, I don’t know. It was in the 1920s. It is a fantastic project that needs to be built, and certainly in your intervention, and I want to take three points that in my opinion are necessary for that.  First of all, on the eurozone and the governance of the eurozone. I agree with you, we don’t need a reform of the eurozone to replace the homework that Member States have to do with new instruments. They have to do their homework. That’s not at stake. What is at stake is that a single currency, at world level, needs fiscal capacity; needs, based on the official capacity, euro safe assets to be used at world level in order to have more harmonious growth inside the eurozone and an instrument against what we call ‘asymmetric shocks’. All this cannot be done through the homework of the Member States alone. There is something common that needs to be tackled. So I agree with you, but the one doesn’t contradict the other, in my opinion.  My second point is on the single market. You said ‘yes, we have the best single market in the world’. I will rectify it a little bit. We could maybe have the best single market in the world when we also have a single market in the markets of the future – digital, energy, capital. I think there is one good solution: create one regulator at European level and, automatically, we shall see the emerging single digital, energy and capital markets.  My third point is on defence. I think the biggest waste of money for the moment in the European Union is the lack and the non-existence of a real European Defence Union. We are spending half the amount of the Americans on military. We have a budget in Europe on military that is three times bigger than the Russians’ budget, but we are not capable, I think, to do our defence alone and that’s because we have 28 times duplication and that’s why I hope, also, that the European Defence Union will be one of the key priorities of the Finnish Presidency.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Prime Minister I wish to thank you very much for joining in this debate on the future of Europe. And while we’re speaking, there are tens of thousands of school students outside in the streets here in Brussels. They’ve also been marching in Finland. And they show us what really matters – to put people and planet before profit. We should really take them seriously. So I want to ask you today Prime Minister to commit to the future, to listen to those young people and to invest in the future when it comes to climate protection, to education and to working together as Europeans. On climate protection, the EU has a huge responsibility and every Member State has to play its role. I’m very happy that you mentioned that you are very committed to that – that you want to go ahead; that you want to have more ambitious climate targets, fantastic! And you’ve mentioned the important role of carbon sinks as well, and Finland is in the lucky position to have a very large carbon sink at hand. The beautiful Finnish forests are an important natural heritage for your country and also largely due to its forests Finland has become the welfare state that it is today. But they are also an important factor indeed in the EU climate policy. The Finnish forests capture 27 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent per year. So it is in our common interest to preserve them, and to manage them sustainably but different from what you said – your government actually plans logging of the Finnish forests, which are not sustainable, which are absolutely excessive, and they will put the huge asset that you have in fighting the climate crisis at risk. So I hope that after your very good speech today, your government will reverse that position to save the great natural heritage that you have, but also to preserve the carbon sinks, because if we wanted to achieve a net zero carbon economy in Europe by 2050 then we need more forests and not less. And rather than telling other countries that they should grow more forests, it is important that we do something in order to keep our own forests. So I’m very happy that you’ve mentioned that you want to have more ambitious targets. We are very much on your side and I am glad to see that you’ve been doing that in the Nordic Council but I hope that you can also bring that to the EU Council, to your fellow Prime Ministers, to make sure that this goes ahead in Europe. That would be an efficient implementation. And the young people that I’ve mentioned – they are also the ones that will run our countries, societies, economies, in the Member States, in the EU, in the not too distant future and I think it is better sooner than later. And education is a big part of preparing them for the task, and Finland is famous for its education system. Everyone came to Finland to copy Finland’s famous school system. But I am sad to see that the current government has been ready to give up its position by cutting almost EUR 1 billion from educational research. But we need more investment into the future, not less. This is also something that we need to talk about, when it comes to the MFF at European level. The European Union must strengthen the social cohesion in Europe and contribute to the welfare of all its citizens and not just those who have good connections to state or businesses. So we need to invest in that. We need to invest in the future and there are so many more tasks that the European Union is given all the time and for that we need adequate resources. So we will not accept a shrinking budget and the Finnish Presidency will be key in order to ensure sufficient finances for the European Union because only then it can efficiently implement its tasks. Mr Prime Minister you also said in your speech how important common values, our rule of law and a united Europe are and you’ve mentioned the danger of populism. I very much agree with that. However, you have experience in working together with a right-wing populist party – this is news to some of your former allies – and I think you’re fully aware of the common challenges that our continent is currently facing. Nationalists and far right movements all across Europe are gaining support by spreading fear and disinformation and pro-European speeches are wonderful; we need them; they’re necessary. But it is by our actions that we truly show where our heart stands and how much our words mean. That’s where we show that we are serious, that we are committed to building that better future together. As Finland’s EU presidency takes place this summer, I hope to see that your country will then be on the progressive side leading the way forward for a united, fair and climate-friendly European Union.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr Prime Minister, I welcome you from the European United Left and the Northern Green Left to the European Parliament. We are once again discussing the future of the Union today. But a future defined by the continuation of the same deadlocked and unpopular policies, policies that promote the impoverishment and disintegration of the social state, which cause the destruction of the environment, which promote militarization and the flirtation of dominant political circles with racism and xenophobia.  How much louder do the peoples of the Union need to say that there needs to be a break with neoliberal austerity policies, a break with policies at the expense of the environment, a break with the policies of the social state? Just last week tens of thousands of students and workers took to the streets of Brussels to change the course of climate policies. In France and elsewhere, workers express their anger and indignation at the policies that make them poor. Even in Finland, which has been an example of a state of social solidarity, society is watching icy scandals resulting from privatisation and deregulation in the health sector: under-staffing on the roofs of elderly people due to privatisation, inappropriate medicines for the elderly, increasing the profit of care companies.  Two years ago from this step President Juncker was forced to admit that the European Union is losing its social character and is in danger of becoming the 'Wild West' of social dumping. But he did not admit what policies led here: policies that produce youth unemployment, poverty, regional and social inequalities, while at the same time smoothing the way for the rise of the far right, racism and xenophobia. Those who do not recognize the cause will obviously continue with the same recipes and on the same path.  Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, what Europe needs today is social justice and social solidarity. The wealth generated for social justice needs to be redistributed fairly, not for banks and multinationals. It needs another way of developing, creating permanent decent jobs and full employment rights; How can the citizens of the Union not be asked why there is EUR 38.5 billion for the new Defence Fund while nursing homes are closing in Finland?  The Union needs a bold policy to tackle climate change. Today, industry defines climate policies according to its own needs. But the peoples demand real solutions. They require political decisions that put a stop to the uncontrolled and unaclyssed action of multinational companies and binding targets to protect the environment and tackle climate change – even more ambitious targets than the Paris Agreement.  Finally, Europe needs an asylum and immigration policy based on international law, humanitarian solidarity with refugees and solidarity between Member States. There is a need to create a permanent mechanism for hosting all refugees in all Member States according to the possibilities of each. Prime Minister, in order to do this we need another Europe, the Europe for which the Left is fighting, the Europe of peace, real solidarity, social justice, the Europe of the peoples.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Prime Minister, the future of the European Union must move from a radical and profound process of change that the citizens of Europe are increasingly demanding. The signs are all there: establishment parties that identify with the political families of the Socialists and The People's Party lose everywhere in Europe and will also lose in the next European elections. Italy is at the head of this process of change. Citizens are fed up with austerity, corruption, injustice, privilege and waste. Thanks to the resources made available by the network, they have united and, from the bottom up, peacefully conquered the government of the country in a few years and sent home a political caste deaf to the needs of the citizens. Let me give you an example of what this change entails: in Italy, in the past, economic manoeuvres were synonymous with social butchery in the name of the stability of public accounts. Today, however, we are giving back resources and dignity to our citizens, focusing on development and employment. With the Italian manoeuvre, we are reducing debt through growth driven by investment and cuts in waste, we have taken away politicians' annuities and financed citizenship income – which Finland knows very well. The income of citizens is in fact an economic manoeuvre in its own right, aimed not at welfare but at the conversion of the labour force. Our goal is to reduce poverty, in Italy there are over 5 million poor people; to enable those outside the labour market to acquire new skills and thus create jobs. Entrepreneurs will have qualified human resources functional to their needs, they will also have recruitment relief; income will relaunch domestic consumption. We want to make Italy stronger in a United Europe of solidarity but also in the world.  Dear President, Europe must be attentive to the false prophets of change, but those who bow before lobbyists. Macron, for example, today lifts the ban on the use of glyphosate in agriculture. This was supposed to start in 2021. The citizens are not stupid, though. Macron backtracks just days before the Aachen summit with Merkel and gives a big gift to Germany's Bayer, which bought Monsanto, in 2018. It changes its mind instead of applying the precautionary principle enshrined in the European Treaties. Do we really want to relaunch Europe? So let us stop hypocrisy and change it, really! The citizens want action. Europe must be a leading player on the world stage and speak with a strong and unique voice. For example, we need a seat for the European Union on the UN Security Council. Instead, with the signing of the Treaty of Aachen, Merkel and Macron are designing their Union of the future; a superpower in which, however, the accounts are paid for by 27 and the decisions, but 2 are taken, excluding, with all the peace of the democratic treaties, 500 million European citizens from the decision-making process. I would remind you that two weaknesses do not make a force; a Europe remote-controlled by Berlin and Paris is exactly the opposite of the demands that citizens are demanding of the whole continent. Italy is the third largest economy in the eurozone, but it does not aspire to hegemonic pretensions, on the contrary it aims to be the guarantor of the chorality of decisions and pluralism. Never before has it been necessary to stress the importance of a political axis that opposes this undue centralisation of power which would make the debate within the institutions meaningless. We are opposed to this dirigisme by participating in and involving from the bottom up. Everyone must have equal dignity in Brussels. The European institutions are perceived as distant from the citizens, it is true. This democratic deficit should be answered not by perched in the building, but by giving the power of legislative initiative and greater powers of control and political direction to the only European institution directly elected by the citizens: the European Parliament, in fact. Does Europe want to change? Then abandon austerity policies that lead to cuts to education, health, pensions and rights. Instead, despite Junker's fake self-criticism of austerity, the path taken is always the same. In this regard, I appeal to all of you, ladies and gentlemen: let us block macro-economic conditionality. To impose sanctions or suspend European funds on a Member State because it does not respect the Brussels diktat is to penalise the regions and citizens even more. European funds are fundamental resources for the development of our territories and for the fight against hydrogeological failure, for example, cutting them would be striking at them. Europe can change if it is on the side of its citizens and if it gives them answers and not slaps down.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, welcome to this Parliament, albeit a little deserted at the moment. The enormous sympathy which, at least in my view, the peoples of Europe have towards your people prevents me from reaching out to the fact that, cynically, it could lead an exponent, like myself, to those populist parties that you are agitating against, to say that every time you declare that you want to host – even at home and above all , which is more serious, in the country – 20-25 thousand immigrants, you bring water to our mill, because in Europe there is a growing awareness – even on the part of those who are certainly neither racist nor xenophobic – that this disorderly immigration only leads to insecurity, difficulties in integration and appalling costs.  Would it not be better to think – as someone intelligently and wisely says, even from certain summits of this Parliament – that we should instead commit ourselves to a Marshall Plan for Africa? The right recipe is not reception, it is not the attempt – very difficult, very difficult, often impossible – of integration – I think, for example, of people of religion and, above all, of Muslim culture, difficult if not impossible to integrate.  Instead, I would have liked to hear from those who represent a great people, a rich nation like Finland, their willingness to join this Marshall Plan. But the appeals made do not coincide with this Europe, which is a little distracted, a little demagogic, which does not realise the seriousness of the problem of immigration and the need and the moral and historical duty of Europe to help the peoples of Africa, not by doing as they have done in the past, by financing wars and speculation, but by means of real aid, perhaps woven through the network of small and medium-sized enterprises. , of those who know how to do business and who could solve the root of the problem of immigration.  Instead, you – excuse me for saying so – have been a little demagogic, giving the impression that you have a demagogic approach to immigration. If I were Finnish – and I would like to be a true Finn – I would advise you to change course and follow the example of those in Europe who, courageously, perhaps running the risk of being accused of xenophobia, racism, etc., choose the right path, the real path, that of our missionaries, who have gone to Africa and brought culture, education and growth. Follow the example of the Italian saint, Don Bosco, who – if he were alive today, as he did in the nineteenth century, in poor Italy – would put in his hands an instrument of work, teach them to work, not to come and peddle, to rape, to do what in their countries, perhaps, these African children never thought to do. The fault for the mistakes and serious crimes committed by immigrants in Europe lies with you and with your demagogy, not with those peoples.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: – Prime Minister, the European Union is facing major problems. The main thing, however, is the fatheristic concept which tends to be established in many of the European governments and in the European institutions. The leaders of the Union act as if they possess the absolute truth and try to impose their ideology on the citizens. Many of the leaders' decisions are irreversible, creating a sense among citizens that democratic control through elections is pointless.  A typical and very recent example is the Prespa Agreement, which was even welcomed by all European leaders. The Greek people expressed their clear opposition, but the Tsipras government was indifferent to creating fait accompli. By concluding this agreement, Europe despises the will of the Greeks and appears to be hostile to Greek interests. I would like to remind you and the other leaders of the Union, and in particular Mr. Tsipras, that your power comes from the people and is valid only as long as the people continue to approve it. But you will soon find that your obsolescence of European nations will awaken the citizens and make them think nationally.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Prime Minister of Finland. – Mr President, thank you very much for the speeches. I will briefly answer the questions I picked up from the speeches. First of all, thank you, Jean—Claude, thank you, Jyrki, for your kind words and the same applies vice—versa. It has been pleasant to work with the Commission. It’s true that it will be a very challenging period of time when our EU Presidency starts. We are forming a new Commission, there will be Parliamentary elections and we will have our own elections before that. There will be multi-annual financial framework (MFF) negotiations, Brexit, the Economic Monetary Union (EMU), and so on. There will be big files on our table. Jean—Claude, you were also right on the Arctic questions. This is absolutely a key part, including with regard to climate change. We are ready for the Arctic Summit in a few weeks if there are circumstances available to arrange that. Jyrki Katainen’s investment fund is an excellent example of how we can create jobs and we have also used this tool in Finland. Mr Weber, congratulations on your nomination. The EPP meeting in Helsinki was very good for me, also because I met about ten colleagues at the same time in the meeting. I agree with you about the economic principles.  The MFF: I have now discussed with 17 colleagues already the situation regarding the MFF and I’m sure that we will find a compromise during our Presidency.  Climate change: I agree that we have to find a sustainable solution, including so that people can live with the solutions. I emphasise that new technology can do much more than we thought. I talked about the CO2 capture from the air. There is a small university in Lappeenranta and I saw the prototype. They captured CO2 from the air and they made other products out of that. The low price of the solar energy is a key solution for that. Think about what kind of possibilities this gives to Africa and for cooperation with African countries.  Mr Kofod, you have learned Finnish in your group. I think that you have some Finnish Members there and there is a good education basis in your group. Finland is the happiest country in the world, but I have to say, at the same time, that we are the best nation to hide it also, if you follow our domestic discussions. I also mentioned the social pillar in my speech. Our priorities are gender equality. We have been leaders in women’s rights in Finland by being the first country in the world to give full political rights to women. Tax havens: I fully agree with what you say about taxation. It should be everyone’s, all the companies, all the countries’ and all the citizens’ values and the basis for regulations that ensure that we pay taxes where the profit is made and this is absolutely the key principle for that. Ms Ruohonen-Lerner, maybe I will answer this question in Finnish. Ehkä tässäkin foorumissa on hyvä sanoa, mistä tuossa taloni luovutuksessa oli kysymys. Kyseessä oli tietämäni iso perhe, joka omassa maassaan oli joutunut vainon kohteeksi kahdesta syystä. Ensinnäkin he olivat auttaneet länsimaalaisia avustustyöntekijöitä ja toiseksi he olivat kristittyjä muslimimaassa. Näin ei pitäisi olla, että vainotuksi joutuu näistä kahdesta syystä. Tämä perhe oli hengenvaarassa joka ikinen päivä. Me emme voi kuvitellakaan, minkälaisissa olosuhteissa he olivat ennen pakoon pääsyänsä. Tämä perhe oli tulossa talooni ja en voinut kuvitellakaan, että Suomessa voisi ilmapiiri kääntyä sellaiseksi, että tuon päätöksen joutuu perumaan perheen turvallisuuden vuoksi. Poliisiviranomaiset sanoivat, että tuon perheen henki on uhattuna myös Suomessa, jos vien päätökseni loppuun. Valitettavasti he eivät tuohon päässeet, mutta he ovat onnellisesti turvassa muualla. Mr President, Guy Verhofstadt has already left – he’s so busy – so I will jump to Ms Keller’s speech on climate change. I have worked a lot on climate-change issues, including at a personal level. I have made a promise that my family will be carbon neutral at the end of next year. I have solar panels at my home, I have an electric car, I have reduced consumption and I have planted trees, so that the end result is carbon neutrality. But it’s too easy for one individual to do this, and we need common action in three forms. We have to lower emissions, and continue on that path, and we also have to increase carbon sinks. There is proof that the Finnish way, a sustainable way, of managing and using the forest is the best way to handle forest, and that also has my strong support. New technology is important too: I am eager to pursue new ways to capture CO2 directly from the air and use that as a source of other new products; and we also have to plant new trees. You mentioned that we have experience of cooperating with a populist party, and my message is that populist parties too should take responsibility as part of a government, in the same way that all of us have to carry responsibility and be answerable to the people. Mr Sylikiotis – I am not sure how to pronounce your name – the famous Finnish left-wing politician Outi Ojala said, in the Finnish Parliament, that the best friend for poor people was a balanced state budget. That is the basis for taking care of everyone, in every country, every day. And that is why, in Finland, social benefits are set at such a high level – besides which, we have equal education for all our citizens. Ms D’Amato, on the employment rate, I agree that the employment rate is the key to balancing the economy, and all your actions in support of development to that end have my support.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Thank you very much for your full responsibility. You have put forward an ambitious plan for the future Finnish Presidency, you have talked a lot about environmental protection, about the economy, about implementing different solutions. You are the Prime Minister of a country with the best European, and I would say even the global educational system. I expected you to devote a great deal of space to education and, although it is the competence of the Member States, you will propose the implementation of the Finnish education system, which today best prepares its young citizens for an unpredictable professional future.  The European Union, in the eyes of the world, is the organisation for which social capital is the most important. So, in an age of robotisation and artificial intelligence, should not be a priority for the Finnish Presidency to prepare European society for the changes that are taking place? Could Europeans, at least during the Finnish Presidency, not learn from the best?

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Prime Minister to the European Parliament. I am very happy to hear that the commitment of the future country of the Presidency is strong. We see that this global situation and shared global challenges and this common future is important. We see that on the other side of the Channel they are trying to do something else – with a lot of problems in finding solutions for Brexit. Mr President, Prime Minister, you also said hello to the readiness to tighten up climate targets, and that is a message that this House is happy to receive. It is just in line, we are moving in roughly the same percentages, and we see that here the objectives are shared and the world expects us to be this pioneer. We also see that R&D efforts and a just transition bring us jobs and well-being, and it is good to commit to this. I agree here with Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the Commission, that Arctic issues are important. Finland cannot be lazy in these. Every border in its neighbouring region, both in the south, in the east and in the north, is important for Europe. And, Mr President, we already have a Mediterranean delegation in this House, and perhaps a delegation on Arctic affairs could already be prepared for the coming period.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr Prime Minister of Finland, Mr Sipilä, I wanted to raise the issue of the European Union's Common Defence Policy. You know, yesterday was the sad anniversary of the Imians. Imia is an area belonging to Greece, two islands belonging to my homeland. But there are Turkey's challenges and doubts. In fact, these days Turkish warships patrol the area. Turkey continues violations in Greek airspace and in Greek territorial waters. It threatens Greece with casus belli if Greece extends its territorial waters to twelve miles. Erdogan wants to overturn the Treaty of Lausanne.  I therefore want a very clear statement, firstly, of Greece's support for the threats of Erdogan and Turkey, secondly, your position to have a European Union policy on the basis of which the European Union will finally support Greece if Turkey challenges its borders. To support the European Union at the borders of Greece, which are also European borders. And we want a very clear position from you, Prime Minister, here in the European Parliament, because it will be a message to Erdogan, to Turkey's threats.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: – Prime Minister Sipilä, I am very pleased that, as an engineer, you emphasise pragility and concreteness in your speeches and also call for this in the Union's actions. The unity of the European Union, and also its economic resilience, is being challenged from many directions and in many ways. They force member states to always reassess the need for cooperation and also their own contribution, so that Europe can also be strengthened in global competition. How do you think, Prime Minister Sipilä, to promote, among other things, the distribution of climate inputs and burden-sharing on immigration issues as evenly as possible between the various Member States? Personally, I think it would be of great importance for the acceptance and confidence of citizens in the Union. And it affects, among other things, the attractiveness and turnout of the spring European elections.  Finally, Prime Minister Sipilä, I would like you, in your next speech, to be able to correct the alleged misconceptions about the state of forest management in Finland.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister, for more than a year your government, together with France and eight other countries, has been blocking any progress in the fight against the export of surveillance technology to dictatorships. Last year, your government, along with the others, drafted a position against the protection of human rights in the dual-use regulation. On the other hand, we in the European Parliament have, with over 92% support, and together with the Commission, put forward a proposal to protect human rights. You will hold the next Presidency. The Council has so far been completely irresponsible, while journalists and human rights activists around the world are being imprisoned and killed with our European technology. I hope you take your responsibilities seriously and change that.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister and colleagues, to this day many Europeans do not feel part of the EU, which makes it easy for populists to control their ideas with fear. Justice is the key to a safer and more people-friendly Europe, whether it is people's livelihoods, work or the fight against climate change, so that everyone can participate according to their own resources, not be left out.  How does Finland intend to promote solutions to justice and inclusion during its presidency, so that Europe, as experienced by the people, is our own Europe, not just a Europe of money and markets and an economy?

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: – Mr President, first of all welcome to Prime Minister Sipilä's European Parliament, this has been called Europe's conscience. There are so many human rights issues that are very important today. I was a little disappointed with the economic policy part of your speech because it had a bit of a yesterday's tone. You placed a great emphasis on budgetary discipline and, at the same time, Finland once again positioned itself among the slightly thinning neoliberals. The second thing I was disappointed about was this part of immigration policy, because that too was a return. In fact, there should be more of a debate in a completely different tone. Especially now, as we approach the twentyth anniversary of the first immigration policy in Tampere, Finland, Europe, the debate should already be on issues other than the return alone. But thank you and thank the President of the Commission for raising the issue of Arctic cooperation. It is also an area where relations between Russia and the EU work well and are therefore valuable.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have two issues to propose to the Finnish Prime Minister, whom I thank. One relates to the European Union's foreign policy, that is to say, the tragedy that a great people, the Venezuelan people, is experiencing and suffering in these hours.  I believe that there is a need for unity in the rights of democracy, peace, the need for peoples to be able to live in freedom, for civil rights, for women's rights, for children's rights and for a system, and I therefore ask the Finnish Prime Minister what his position is and whether he believes that Juan Guaidó is recognized, including by the Finnish Prime Minister himself. , as the legitimate President of Venezuela.  The other major issue is anti-dumping, unfair competition, the economy and international trade. Our businesses need more protection.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Prime Minister, I am pleased that we are here today in this position, you as Prime Minister of Finland, Me as the MEP of the country holding the Presidency of the Council of the European Union. I tell you this because it has caused a great political scandal, but especially in the media, your statement that you are ready to take over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union directly from Bulgaria. I am convinced that you have been misled by President Johannis' statements, but, Prime Minister, at your level you should have known that the government has powers in the exercise of the Presidency of the Council of the European Union in Romania. So the only political actor whose statements you should take into account is the Prime Minister of Romania. I am convinced that now, a few months after that inappropriate statement, you have changed your mind, especially since in just one month since taking over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, Romania has already closed some important dossiers. My message to you is continuity. I hope that you will continue and I am thus convinced that you will continue the projects started by Romania at the Presidency of the Council of the European Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, Dear Mr. Sipilä, I agree with you that the Union, if it wishes to promote certain values in its foreign policy, must also protect those values in its own backyard. However, the value component of this community must not be subject to arbitrary interpretations aimed at establishing a framework imposed by several members with brussels administration.  Values should be a generally accepted source around which all members gather. Using financial mechanisms to force certain members to adopt a dominantly liberal narrative and disregard the national interest is completely unacceptable. Union values should bring us together and must not be used to subjugate the disobedient with undeniable electoral legitimacy.  Our slogan is "United in diversity", but reality says that we are disjoyed in imposed uniformity. Let's get back to recognising diversity and subsidiarity and work on consensus instead of imposition.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, welcome to this debate. Usually it is visited with an emblem that it is easier to see the weed in the neighbor's eye than a cup in your own. Two points I would like to raise here, you spoke about a balanced budget and, at the same time, you also talked about the great demands and challenges facing Europe. In my opinion, this arrangement does not really go according to the correct engineer's calculiway. We need, as you also said, balanced compromises, and Finland will now be the author of these balanced compromises during its Presidency. I would like the current Finnish Government, which may not be sitting for very long, to take over this issue in a very tomeric manner and then get things done in such a way that we can proudly look to the Finnish Presidency.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, welcome Prime Minister, Mr Juncker said that even some of the founding countries of the EU could learn from Finland. This means that Finland has always wanted to build the European Union. Now I'd like to ask you two things. What is Finland's position and how do you assess the possibilities of achieving certain tax decisions by qualified majority, rather than allowing any Member State to block tax-related decisions at present? This would be precisely the way to stamp out tax avoidance and safeguard the financial base of the welfare state. I know that this is on the Council's table and that Finland, at least in principle, has not been very happy to support this, because it is about the sovereignty of the state, but are you prepared to change your position here? Another question about corporate responsibility, in Finland there is a very active campaign to regulate such a corporate responsibility law. Everyone believes that it should be regulated at EU level so that all companies have to report and bear the human rights, environment and other impacts of their activities. Could this be one of the priorities of finland's Presidency?

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, it is good to see you here in the European Parliament and especially in a year like this, when Finland is preparing for the EU Presidency for the third time. It is important for the European Parliament to hear what Finland's priorities are. I have to say that I myself was a little surprised, and perhaps a little disappointed, at the limited role played by education, skills and research in that speech. If we think about what Finland's success has been based on over the past decades, it is based precisely on the fact that we have good education, a good level of competence and good research. It has made Finland one of the most innovative countries in the world. That is precisely the message that Europe needs for its own future now, if we are thinking about how to create sustainable growth in Europe, how we will remain competitive in such a situation when the digital economy is changing the world. Robotisation, automation change working life and, on the other hand, we are facing major global challenges, which you rightly highlighted climate change and the fight against it. What we need here is good skills, training, high-quality research. I hope that this will also be a strong message for Finland during the forthcoming Presidency. The European Parliament wants to increase European research money by 50%. Finland is one of the countries that has made research funding one of MFF's top priorities. I would now like confirmation as to whether this is the line that Finland will take forward in the MFF negotiations?

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, today we are again witnessing a debate on the future of the European Union. And I believe that in that future there are two revolutions that will mark our lives: the technological or digital revolution and the energy revolution. The European Union must therefore face these challenges.  To the challenge of the energy revolution that will mark our lives, our way of travel, our way of consuming, etc. being ambitious in the fight against climate change, which is the great challenge that humanity has. In this legislature, very important steps have been taken to put Europe as the leader of this energy transition. As a leader to achieve decarbonization and achieve climate goals. But we can't let our guard down, because the challenge is very important and the answer has to be constant.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Democracy, the rule of law are the foundations on which the European Union is built. The fundamentals are increasingly being broken, but the European Union's value is also the common market, the free movement of services, people and goods. And here, too, there is a noticeable desire to restrict these freedoms.  Finland, despite lying on the outskirts of the European Union (to reach Brussels from Helsinki, the truck needs five days), supported the General Approach of the Council of the European Union on the mobility package. At the same time, Finnish MEPs voted in favour of exempting international transport from the rules on posting. And here I have a question, Prime Minister: do you not think that, in support of the solutions proposed by the Council, you are actually restricting economic freedoms? You are not removing trade barriers, and yet you have said that these barriers need to be dismantled, that at the same time it may turn out that many small and medium-sized enterprises will have to liquidate their activities and that consumers, including Finnish consumers, will pay the price for the increase in the prices of services and goods.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, I agree with many things you have said here. You have talked about cohesion, you have talked about the rule of law, and here I want to refer, Prime Minister, to some concrete things in your country. You said that there should be no rebate on the rule of law and I agree. But do you know that there are laws in your country that do not apply? Do you know that there are families from which children have been taken, children at 12 years old who, under Finnish law, have the right to appear in court, to opt for the mother and are not heard in court? There are atrocities in institutions that institutionalise children, Prime Minister. I made you a letter, no action was taken. How can we have a rule of law when citizens, who are Europeans, are a citizen of my country, do not have the same rights as the citizens of Finland? And please answer me on time! And, of course, I wish there was no conditionality in the MFF, as you claim it, because, behold, it defines itself differently and distinctly for each country the rule of law.

name: Mirja VEHKAPERÄ
text: – Mr President, the speech by The Finnish Prime Minister Juha Sipilä was a concrete, firm and, in particular, warming up finland's Presidency of the Council of the EU. You presented the utilisation of our forest expertise. Finland has almost 70 per cent of finland's land area, so if anyone has expertise in forest management and also sustainable use, we have expertise. The European and African Forest Fund must be supported from both a climatic and an employment perspective. However, parliamentarians in this Chamber and the European Parliament should also look to northern Arctic issues. Where I live in the Arctic, where I live, there is a great deal of potential and something to give to Europe. We have rich natural resources, nature, know-how above all else, but we also urgently and fervently need Europe's contributions here to the Arctic. That is what I hope for in the future.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Prime Minister Sipilä for being here and making the case for Finland as a happy country after 25 years in the European Union and making up one percent of the total population of the European Union. You got started talking about history, Prime Minister, and I would like to quote one of the founding fathers, a former Prime Minister of Belgium, Paul-Henri Charles Spaak. He once said it’s not true that the European Union is a blend between big and small states: we are all small in relation to the challenges of the world to come. It is just that some countries know this, and other countries don’t know it yet. You spoke of a challenge, namely defence and security, and that is meaningful in view of Finland’s neutral past, but you said less about migration. I urge you to overcome the temptation of populism, and to gather up the forces necessary to unblock the Dublin Regulation, as this has been the mandate of the European Union. It takes a common policy and solidarity when it comes to migration, and no country can turn a blind eye to those in need who are knocking on the Union’s doors.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: –Mr President, Prime Minister Sipilä, you will see that you are welcome here when finns have so many questions that it is beginning to feel that this is Question Time in Parliament, but here in the European Parliament we are behaving better than during Question Time in the Finnish Parliament, not fumbly. My question concerns when you emphasised the implementation of decisions. I agree with you that one major shortcoming is that ambitious decisions are taken, but then the Member States do not implement them. My question is this: is it more the Member States? What can be done to do homework together? Have these decisions been adequately prepared here at the Council of the European Union meetings, even at the Prime Minister's meetings there? Because it seems strange that, after these meetings, results and good team spirit are proclaimed, and then, when you go home, nothing happens. What can be done? What would you do to ensure that joint decisions are implemented?

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Prime Minister of Finland. – Mr President, thank you all for the questions.  We in Finland are used to this kind of questioning. Every Thursday at 4 o’clock in our Parliament is Question Hour. All ministers have to be present and we are used to this. But we give our answer right after each question. Now I have 30 questions to answer at the same time, so I will conclude with some top—lines.  First education. Education and equal education is very important for Finland. Public school is the best school for rich people and poor people. All the people in Finland, all the kids, go to the same school. We have the best teachers in the world and we have a challenge to educate about one million Finnish people during the next ten years. I think that this same challenge is in every European Union country because of artificial intelligence, because of the changes in work life. Climate change – thank you for supporting my speech and all the issues I raised with regard to climate change. Arctic issues are very important for Finland. We are especially worried about black carbon, and this is a quite concrete issue where we can negotiate also with Russia and the United States, which are not very keen to support climate change actions. We need also R&B investments, that’s true in this sector. Defence cooperation – Finland has supported defence cooperation from the beginning. I really welcome the progress on that issue. There was a question about Turkey. It’s very complicated. It’s a NATO country and the rule of law developments in that country worry us a lot – the situation in Greece and Cyprus also.  As for the Romanian Presidency, I have always been sure that Romania will do an excellent job as the Presidency of the European Union, and there has been some proof of that already. Venezuela – our full support to democratic development and elections. The humanitarian situation in that country is really bad at the moment and I am sure Finland will follow everything that we decide together in the European Union.  There were some – actually quite a few – questions in Finnish. So I will conclude my answers in Finnish.  Ensinnäkin kestävä metsänhoito: Suomessa käytetään puun kasvusta 70–80 prosenttia ja Suomen metsät kasvavat koko ajan enemmän kuin käytämme puuta. Puuta käytetään koko ajan paremmin ja tehokkaammin myöskin sillä tavalla, että hiili sitoutuu pitkäksi aikaa niihin tuotteisiin, joita teemme metsistä ja puista. MFF:stä kysyttiin täällä useamman kerran. Tulevana puheenjohtajamaana olen aivan varma näiden käymieni kollegakeskusteluiden perusteella siitä, että tulemme löytämään kompromissin, missä tämä perinteinen EU-politiikka ja uudet haasteet pystytään sovittamaan yhteen. Emme ole olleet siellä kaikkein tiukimmassa prosentin liikkeessä vaan meillä on jouston varaa myöskin kotimaisessa kannassamme, ja puheenjohtajana tulemme löytämään siihen ajallaan oikean ratkaisun.  Täytäntöönpanosta puhuin paljon tuossa puheessani. Meillä Suomessa on tapana, että kun yhdessä sovitaan jotakin, varsinkin tällaisella joukolla, niin sitten me teemme osuutemme siitä yhdessä tehdystä päätöksestä välittömästi. Tästä varmasti meillä on tarpeeksi näyttöä.  So implementation is a key issue: when we have carefully prepared our decisions we then implement everything efficiently. I think this is a key message from my speech. Mr President, thank you very much. It was a pleasure to be here and it was a very interesting discussion. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you very much, Prime Minister. Thank you for your answers. I also thank you for your position on Venezuela.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – When discussing the deepening of EMU and the banking union, the possible merger between Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank is now on the agenda. This merger would create a banking megagroup with around €2 billion in assets, with a european top position. Several analysts recall that the two institutions have had some difficult years. Deutsche Bank posted losses between 2015 and 2017 and Commerzbank re-organized its activities through a sharp reduction in its workforce. In short, the low level of own funds of both institutions makes it possible to foresee a scenario of some reserve. This merger between these institutions will accentuate the problem of large financial institutions with systemic effect that were the basis of public intervention after the financial crisis. It will create excessive market power, enhancing abuses of dominance with serious damage to the economy. In a moment it will once again confirm the role of the ECB and the Single Supervisory System as active promoters of banking concentration within the European Union.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: We are pleased to welcome a delegation from the Parliament - Mazhilis - from Kazakhstan, chaired by Mr. Mukhtar Erman, to the diplomatic gallery. The delegation is here in Brussels to participate in the 16th EP-Kazakhstan Parliamentary Cooperation Committee. We are very pleased to host this important meeting which will strengthen our dialogue and cooperation. It is an honour to have you at the heart of European democracy today, and your presence is a sign of our shared commitment to promoting human rights and political pluralism through the rule of law. On behalf of the entire European Parliament, I wish you a fruitful meeting and a good stay in Europe.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Madam President, I rise under Rule 11(3). According to Politico, our distinguished colleague Elmar Brok finds it necessary to generate cash from visitors’ groups. It would appear that his salary and payment from Bertelsmann are not sufficient. I therefore propose that we make a collection in Mr Brok’s honour. (Applause) I would like to set the ball rolling by donating five cents – for the benefit of the interpreters, that’s five centimes. Perhaps someone else will improve on that.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Madam President, I would like to raise a question of observance on the basis of Article 22 of the Rules of Procedure of this Parliament: 'The President shall direct, in accordance with this Rules of Procedure, all the activities of Parliament and its bodies. It shall have all the powers to preside over Parliament's deliberations and ensure its normal development'. Yesterday's speech by Mr Tajani claiming that he has spoken to the self-styled President Guaidó to assure him of the European Parliament's support by moving forward with a debate and a vote contravies the Rules of Procedure of this House, and I want an official response.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls Voting Time.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, between liberticidal amendments on the composition of groups, which have never been discussed in the committee responsible, and the request to vote by secret vote on amendments providing for greater transparency in this institution – secrecy in transparency, beautiful political oxymoron, we will never end up being surprised – this reform of the Rules of Procedure is becoming a farce: a sad and undignified spectacle , which brings the European Parliament into disrepute.  As Vice-President, I feel a duty to protect its reputation; As a Member of Parliament, I have a duty to ensure that the will of the citizens who demand transparency is respected; As a European citizen, I have a duty to demand that pluralism and democracy be respected in this House.  That is why, on behalf of the EFDD Group, I am calling, pursuant to Rule 188(2), for this text to be referred back to committee, which is in danger of becoming a terrible boomerang for the honour and reputation of this Parliament.  Thank you also for the great democracy that you have been able to express in this context.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Madam President, yes indeed, I would like to speak against this. The report before you has been discussed for almost a year in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. There was a special working group, comprised of one representative from every single political group, which prepared this. It had a high level of consensus, and now it comes to plenary to be voted on and, like any report coming to plenary for vote, it is subject to amendments, and we will vote on those. It has already been postponed from the December to the January I part-session, then it was postponed from January I to January II. I rather suspect that if we postpone it until February there will then be a proposal to postpone it until March, and then April and then May. This is beginning to sound a little bit like Theresa May! (Applause)

name: Elmar BROK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The colleague will one day have to apologise for the allegations. Secondly, I know that was the answer to my speech on Brexit yesterday. That's always the thing: when things get uncomfortable, someone is personally defamed. I believe That I will never reveal the interests of Ireland and the European Union for people who would accept money would be morally irresponsible.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, since we drafted the Joint Resolution so far, Ronaldo Rodríguez, José Salas, Baptiste des Monstiers, Pierre Caillé, Gonzalo Domínguez, Leonardo Muñoz and Maurén Barriga have been arrested in Venezuela. All of them are journalists who worked for two European media and who were doing their job. From the information just given in Spain by the President of the EFE Agency, they are now in the dungeons of the secret service. We defend the position we stand for in this House, all of us are in favour of freedom of expression, and we are all in favour of the media being able to report freely, because we all believe that freedom of information is the very life of democracy.  Therefore, in accordance with the other proponents of the Joint Resolution, we request that a new paragraph be added after paragraph 4. Paragraph 4a, which would say: 'Condemns the detention of several journalists covering the situation in Venezuela and calls for their immediate release'. (Parliament accepted the oral amendment).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: It is a pleasure to announce that the European Parliament recognises Juan Guaidó as venezuela's legitimate interim president.  The European Parliament is the first European institution to do so and we call on the Member States and the high representative to do the same as soon as possible in order to have a unique and strong position.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: – Madam President, after Venezuela, there is also another country that is violating human rights – there is no democracy, they are oppressing women and they are cutting dissidents into pieces – and that is Saudi Arabia. I hope we will vote for regime change in Saudi Arabia … (Sustained applause) After all, there is oil there! There is oil! We have to change the regime.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: This closes Voting Time.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, just to say that I am extremely happy, also on behalf of my political group, that common sense has prevailed in this House.  The Corbett report, which does indeed introduce some good measures into our regulation, was, however, largely marred by two deadly risks, in our opinion: on the one hand, there was the problem of transparency. If there were any amendments which I fully support in this respect, there was also the will of the Group of the European People's Party to use secret voting. We have seen that, fortunately, this secret vote was in favour of the amendments that we strongly supported.  In addition to this, there was, of course, the well-known issue of the enormous abuse of power, allowing a majority to decide on the status of oppositions. But we have seen that it has not received an absolute majority in this House and I am pleased that my fellow Members have prevailed over the principle of democratic representation and pluralism in this Chamber, defeating those who wanted to give all the power in the hands of the groups of the ancien regime.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Madam President, for the past 30 years, I have witnessed the constant erosion of minority rights in this increasingly corporalist and increasingly politically correct parliament, in this institution which speaks only of minority rights, respect for the rule of law, the guarantee of freedoms and which practises very little in internal use. There is nothing missing from the Corbett report: a complete infantilisation of MPs, a guilt of the white male, which is quite in line with gender theory; we will now have to undergo internships to learn that it is very wrong sexual harassment and to sign statements to that effect; MEMBERS will no longer be able to meet with their interlocutors without this being immediately made public in the name of transparency. I want to exclaim: transparency, that crimes are committed in your name. This assembly becomes a primary school, and I will be happy to leave it.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, I welcome this report that has been brought forward by my colleague Richard Corbett. I welcome all the recommendations, particularly on the Members’ Code of Conduct, but I specifically want to mention the recommendation on parliamentary questions – that they should be answered within six weeks.  In an answer to a question that I asked the Commission about questions last year, it stated that just 32% of written questions to the Commission were answered within that six—week timeframe. Now I don’t know where members of the Commission went to school, but I’m sure in anyone’s book 32% is not a particularly impressive or acceptable grade.  On this the Commission is going to have to do better. So when these recommendations are discussed in interinstitutional discussions, this is something Parliament I think has to take a strong position on. Questions are an important mechanism for us as Members in holding the Commission to account and seeking information to support our work.  32% last year is not good enough; the six—week limit is important.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, I am pleased with the outcome of this report because I opposed the limitation to be imposed on the establishment of parliamentary groups, because it seems to me that it was technically very poorly done and that it was politically a restriction of rights and freedoms which I cannot endorse in any way.  I think it is technically a bad proposition because the concepts being handled were totally arbitrary and both the definition of what ideological coherence of groups means and the ideas that were managed to measure it did not support minimal analysis.  I would also like to remind you that some of the groups that already exist in this House would immediately lead to their dissolution, and others simply punish the principle of freedom of vote and conscience which assists all Parliamentarians.  That is why I would not want to be in the role of anyone who had to really explain a rule that allows this level of arbitrariness, and I would not like it because I am a Democrat and I believe in the rule of law. And those who aren't love these tools because they allow that arbitrariness. When such indefinite concepts are used in law, freedoms are always used to attack democracy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, first of all I would like to say, in order to put it on the record completely procedurally, that in the Selimovic report my machine did not work. If it worked, I'd vote against it. Now, in relation to this report, I would like to say that the attempt of the major political groups to impose what they wanted, namely to judge them on what conditions political groups will be formed, has failed, because the concept of political affiliation is not something that the plenary itself would have regulated. I analyzed that yesterday. From then on, there must be further improvements to the Rules of Procedure, particularly with regard to the preventive control exercised by the Bureau in relation to questions, because we ask questions and ultimately the Bureau of the European Parliament checks whether they are correct and rejects them or not. This is unacceptable and it should be stopped.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of amendments to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament because I believe that being seriously in politics is not being held hostage by ideologies or captured by interest groups. It is rather possible to solve the problems of citizens and project the future of the European Union and its Member States, cultivating the values of human development while respecting individual freedom and defending democracy. It is therefore necessary to increase transparency and availability of information on the relations maintained by MEPs for the activities of drafting legislative acts in the multiple contacts developed with civil society. We have to rest our constituents from which we hear all the voices, because to listen to the diversity of opinions is to address the concerns of the citizens of the European Union, to ensure that we build a Europe without trampling and to ensure that we defend the right causes for which we have been elected. Supporting secrecy is halfway to creating the conditions for corruption and harboring the trafficking of influences under the same roof of democracy, and for that it does not count on me. For these reasons, Europe has already suffered enough.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I am pleased to support the amendments to the Rules of Procedure drafted by my good friend Richard Corbett, despite the fact that there were secret ballots on two votes relating to Amendment 20 of this report. I want to make it very clear and for it to be on the record that I voted in favour of the mandatory legislative footprint for rapporteurs, shadows and chairs, and indeed for increased transparency on the general expenditure allowance. I consistently publish any meetings I have across all my social media channels and always host visitors in public areas of Parliament where I am visible by all. We must be committed to transparency and accountability across the EU and its institutions. Transparency builds trust with our constituents and allows them confidently to put their faith in their representatives. Furthermore, I would like to put on the record that I disagree with having these two secret ballot votes. This is not how we should operate in Parliament. I am proud of the work I do on behalf of my Irish constituents and want to have this known. Finally, I am pleased to vote in favour of the amendment regarding mandatory anti-harassment training. Having already completed a training myself, I recommend it to other MEPs as well.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Colleague Corbett's report is highly controversial and the amendments tabled therein aim at limiting democratic freedom. The requirement for political groups to provide political declarations signed by all their members in which to declare their political affiliation is contrary to any rules and procedures that this Parliament has consistently stated to protect. I am pleased that from the text we have been able to remove the requirement that the European Parliament be able to assess whether political groups are formed according to the political affiliation of all parties to one political family. This cannot be proven and is absolutely untenable. For me, this is a tool with which large political groups, when they are scared that they will lose their supremacy, will desperately try to retain that supremacy and spoil other political groups.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I agree that more transparency and accountability in the decision-making is needed. However, I cannot agree with the concept of political affinity for the formation of political groups in the European Parliament. We do not have concrete criteria and parameters for that, apart from the fact that the word ‘affinity’ does not have any legal force. As we can see from the results, the votes of the Group can be inconsistent and incoherent on some issues. We have the freedom of vote, and this is something our electorate relies on. We represent the citizens and the residents of the European Union to advance their needs, and we cannot do it if we are strictly limited by belonging to the Group. In order not to make the EP dysfunctional and in order that it will continue to be a truly democratic institution, we must continue the practice of free and voluntary Group formation. That is why I abstained.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, the debate has tended to focus on the plans here to make life harder for small Groups: Groups that challenge the orthodoxy or represent dissident opinions. No surprise here; I think even my federalist colleagues will admit that this has been the theme of the reforms of this Parliament over some time. Despite all the rhetoric we get about tolerance, there is an intolerance of people who run up against the challenged views on European integration.
