But I just wanted to draw the House’s attention to Amendment 14 of the Parliament’s Rules of Procedures, which is a deletion, and one of the lines deleted is this one: ‘the application of this rule shall not otherwise detract from the liveliness of parliamentary debates, nor shall it undermine Members’ freedom of speech’. That’s deleted. I suppose the one argument that could be made is that this House, in its new attitude to free speech, is at least in line with changing mores in Europe as a whole. Still, what a sad comment for what is, at the end of the day, a parliament. As the etymology of that word implies, it is a place one ought to be able to talk freely.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab An amendment has been tabled to ensure that governing majority groups can dissolve opposition groups. The vote on it shows that several hundred people supported this amendment, so the threat to democracy in Europe should not be sought in some small, marginal neo-fascist groups, only here in this Chamber. I think it is hypocridous when one day we insist on freedom of expression in Venezuela, and we restrict freedom of expression in this House once again. An MEP should only be accountable to his constituents and not to his political opponents, because any tools to control Members, however demagogically justified here: good, transparency, hate speech, etc., can serve as a tool of repression. And this is absolutely unacceptable.  I hope that history will mock those who want to control the minority today, being mostly, and after some changes, perhaps someday some of their political opponents will be harassing them for hate speech. For example, I would consider hate speech to demand privileges for women – that is, hate speech against men – or to increase taxes is a tool of economic oppression.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this proposal. I would like to explain my vote on offensive speech and to follow up on my colleague Sośnierz.  I personally voted against this proposal, i.e. in favour of respecting the greater freedom of Members in their speeches. However, this does not mean that, in my opinion, it should be said offensively. On the other hand, I want to respect the view expressed by the European Court of Justice, even if I completely disagree with it.  Mr. Sośnierz joined Mr. Mikke here. We have heard so many insults from this gentleman. It seems that we will have to be some way more resistant to these statements, for which reason I did not support this particular amendment. We will have to be more resilient, but I think we should speak well in this House.  Otherwise, I welcome the adoption of the amendments that have been tabled, and I think it is good to tame it when it comes to lobbying.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, I am happy to welcome the proposals in this report as well-intentioned, particularly in the context of meetings with lobbyists. My fear, however, as someone who has worked in the public affairs industry, is that this will prove ineffective, and my further fear is that this will put into the public domain information that is easily distorted by those of less good intentions that will present a false impression of what Members are seeking to do. So I urge the Conference of Presidents to keep this under review. I would add my view to Mr Palmer’s view on the need to produce answers to questions more quickly. On the question of political groups, we all know that Groups like UKIP have abused the rules of this place, and it’s right to try to stop them. But my fear is also that that would not produce the result that was intended. On the question of secret ballots on votes on transparency, please: it’s absurd. I support them.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, a proper report on public spending and the protection of the EU's financial interests – these words are not just an empty phrase. On the contrary, our important mission is to carefully supervise the proper and efficient use of the money of all EU citizens in order to strengthen citizens' trust.  I come from the Czech Republic and the suspicion of misuse of European funds unfortunately extends us to the highest levels of politics. I am therefore aware of the importance of combating fraud, in which we must continue to insist, despite the encouraging fact that overall improvements are being made and the number of frauds and irregularities is decreasing. That is why I supported this report.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, the annual report on the protection of financial interests and the fight against fraud in the European Union highlights the damage done by the large lobbies which, by entering the institutions or, conversely, with the so-called 'revolving door effect', exercise a strong power of conditioning or corruption. It also expresses its strong concern about controls on financial instruments managed by intermediaries and the control of beneficiaries' legal sites. Finally, it states that intra-Community VAT fraud costs the Eu ropean Union around EUR 50 billion every year.  Compared to the general decrease in irregularities in 2017, there is a worrying countertrend regarding direct aid in agriculture, with an average value for each case of fraud increased by as much as 227 %. Is it possible that everything is fine, except in one area? Is it not the fact that there are gaps in the overall detection of fraud? This question is all the more urgent in view of the fact that some countries do not report any kind of fraud. How is that possible? Is it not the case that some states, fearful of controls on their own budgetary laws and therefore on the economic governance process imposed by the European Union, prefer to cheat on anti-corruption monitoring, reducing the sending of data or even not sending it at all? In the light of these negotiations, how can the Commission not consider it necessary to publish the report on combating corruption? Why is that?  Ladies and gentlemen, if corruption and fraud are to be combated in order to safeguard the interests of European citizens, controls must be increased and their quality improved. The Commission should identify strict indicators and uniform criteria that must be adopted in a binding manner by all Member States. We need prevention and law enforcement actions that are decisive and harmonised throughout Europe. Olaf must be given access to the data and information necessary to carry out the necessary checks.  Since all these considerations have been largely expressed in the report, I voted in favour.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the fight against fraud in relation to the management of Community funds and VAT, I think, needs to be intensified. In this Chamber we have denounced the 'party' made by the various NGOs in Greece, which have really used huge funds on the issue – supposedly – of the protection of refugees but in practice we see that refugees are now cold in winter. Here in this Chamber I have made specific complaints. We still have a result from OLAF, we still have a result from the Commission. The second issue is fraud in the field of agricultural policy, because what is happening is to baptize foreign agricultural and livestock products as Greek; So we have Greekization of milk imported from Albania, Greekization of meat imported from Skopje and concrete measures must be taken. Mr Oettinger was also committed to the Commission's intervention in this matter. We are still waiting for action to be taken.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The introduction of new ad hoc items on the agenda very often unfortunately takes away the chances of a serious debate on those points that have been planned in advance. It seems to me that there may be exceptions in this matter, but unfortunately they are becoming the rule.  That is why there are now two brief observations on the report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests. The first – to pessimists, the second – to optimists. The former is mainly related to the decreasing number of cases, irregularities reported in 2017 compared to 2016; decreased to €2.58 billion. But to the satisfied optimists, I would like to draw attention to the second thing: compared to 2016, fraud alone is €0.5 billion, an increase of nearly 20%.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – I voted against Mr Marinescu's report because I believe that national sovereignty matters and must finally be respected and protected. The report acknowledges that the total number of irregularities 15,213 cases were investigated in 2017, 20% less than in 2016, when there were 19,080 cases, and that their value as damage decreased by 13% from EUR 2.97 billion in 2016 to EUR 2.58 billion in 2017.  While the fight against all corruption is a legitimate objective and the call for closer cooperation between the Member States of the European Union with regard to the exchange of information is also a legitimate objective and is something that I and my group certainly support, the report also contains some controversial aspects, namely the references to more action at European level that would take away the sovereignty of the Member States , whose competences include the fight against organised crime.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, the Lisbon Treaty says that Member States must fight against fraud affecting the financial interests of the Union as they do to counter the fraud affecting their own financial interests. Unfortunately, the corruption in the Member States does not stop at their borders, and it has a spill-over effect to the EU. As a result, we lose both citizens’ trust in national public administration and in EU institutions. I wish all our national police and investigation authorities would read the report tomorrow, instead of the morning paper. The figures are really alarming. VAT fraud costs the Union around EUR 15 billion annually. OLAF very rarely carries our investigations into irregularities concerning VAT, due to a lack of instruments. Since it’s clear that we cannot fully rely on the efforts of 28 or 27 national anti-fraud systems, we need to give more possibilities to OLAF.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, the obvious question about protecting the EU’s financial interests arises in the context of the EUR 50 billion deficit that will be the consequence of a no-deal Brexit, and it was very clear in this Chamber, listening to the debate yesterday, that that is now the way in which people here want to head. There’s a complete unwillingness to show any flexibility that would result in a deal. And yet I was amazed to discover yesterday that, at the same time, the European Commission expects the money to be paid even in the event that there is no deal. The United Kingdom was happy to sign up to more than any international court would think was a strict liability for the sake of good relations and facilitating a future trade relationship. But if there is no deal, you don’t get to tell us what to do anymore.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I supported this report because, firstly, I want to appreciate developments which mean that fewer fraud and fewer irregularities are precisely in the handling of European money. I think that's a very positive trend, although sometimes this percentage decreases in that year-on-year comparison and sometimes rises a little bit, so this trend is positive. We need to motivate the judiciary to deal with all cases with the principle of who to fall for.  At the same time, I would like to express and appreciate the amendment which highlights the role of investigative journalists in this report. We have tragic cases here from Malta, from Slovakia. I would like to draw particular attention to the risk of linking the power of political, economic and media. We are also seeing this in the Czech Republic. When these components come together, the democratic brakes stop working. I think that This, too, should be remembered by European law.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation on the .eu domain. It may seem more like a technical issue, but there is a clear overlap to promote the EU's visual identity in the Member States and in the overall internet environment across borders. Nowadays, the Internet is also connected with the issue of data protection and human rights, and the EP's position remembers this protection. I also agree that the domain should be extended to the entire European economic area, because economic connectivity is large in this area and desirable. This is in the interest of economic growth for both the EU and the Member States.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab After the debate, I received a few questions. First of all: why was this domain review? And: what are the conclusions of this review? It seems that the debate did not give a sufficient answer to these two questions. I would point out – the review itself was primarily because we have a gigantic growth of the domains themselves, and it is the highest level, that is, those that dominate and determine the quality of the functioning of the IT market, information in this matter. But what is its effect? This is the most important thing. I would like to emphasise four points. Firstly, the removal of outdated legal requirements, including administrative requirements, and the updating of the rules itself. Secondly, to further mainstream and promote the European Union's priorities in the online world, more effective. Thirdly, the relaxation of the existing eligibility criteria for domain registration. Fourthly, finally, the abolition of the prohibitions on vertical separation, that is to say, provisions requiring a strict distinction between organisations managing domain names, registrations and entities involved in their sale.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, firstly, my congratulations to our wonderful colleague Frederick Federley for his work on this report, which I had the pleasure of voting to support. The .eu top-level domain name is well established in a fast-flowing top-level domain (TLD) market. In a digital landscape that is constantly evolving, it is crucial that the legal framework for the .eu TLD is updated appropriately and that we secure flexible regulation for the future. This will assist in the promotion of EU values, including respect for users’ privacy and security, consumer protection, human rights and multilingualism. To this end, I support an assurance that all residents of EU Member States and organisations established in the EU be allowed to register a .eu TLD. I particularly welcome the mandatory revocation of a domain name when it has been used in bad faith, and I am also in favour of an assessment by the Commission of possible cooperation between the registry and the EU Intellectual Property Office.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I welcome the report drafted by my colleague, Mr Federley, and I voted in favour. Although the .eu top-level domain (TLD) functions well, it is also true that the online environment and market are evolving very quickly, and we should always think one step ahead. Therefore, the legal framework governing the domain has to be adapted. The .eu domain is also an element of our common online identity. Therefore, we have to be careful with what falls under this domain name. Multilingualism, respect for privacy and security, consumer protection, human rights: yes, all these principles must be upheld for granting this domain name. The European Parliament has to exercise major control over it and should be able to establish the criteria in the procedure for the registry.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This report is an example of the European Union ideologising everything it will do. Even the silly two letters at the end of the domain can dress up in some improbable statements about protecting European identity. It wants to make this dependent on the promotion of EU values. I am sure that even if we were debating potatoes here, it would turn out that potato can be a tool for European identity and the promotion of EU values. It is simply pathetic to make it dependent on whether someone can buy a domain, whether they live here or not, whether they profess values, and whether the domain will serve multilingualism. It means that if it is not translated into any languages, it may not be possible to purchase such a domain or will it be received? Really, it's all so sad that it's so funny, and maybe so funny, that it's so sad. I voted against it.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, this report means that, in the event of a no-deal Brexit, the .eu domain name will be lost overnight in the UK. It’s something I use and something that the East of England Local Government Partnership Office uses. Sadly, this is an office that is threatened with imminent closure, as EELGA want to pull the financial plug. Now I appreciate the huge financial pressures on local government, but shutting the office is foolhardy, throwing down the drain experienced specialist knowledge, contacts and goodwill. Because Plan A Brexit, Plan B Brexit, hard Brexit, soft Brexit, no Brexit at all: as a region I am sure that we will still want to do business with other European regions. So why put up a ‘closed’ sign on the east of England? So today I urge an urgent rethink. We are a global player in life sciences, communications and manufacturing. So let us do the right thing by our region and keep an office where the East meets the rest of the world.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Madam President, eight are the resolutions that this Parliament has already issued on the situation in Venezuela. And eight are the resolutions that nothing has contributed to solving the crisis in Venezuela. With the recognition of the self-proclaimed Guaidó, you are validating a coup that, to the misfortune of the Venezuelan people, has inevitable visions of ending in military intervention or civil war.  Today, instead of marking a profile of its own, calling for dialogue and peace, as the Secretary-General of the United Nations has done, the European Union has decided to become Trump's servant by supporting his crazy policy of interventionism and adding itself to reckless bilateral recognition that only pours more gasoline into the fire.  And it is curious that Guaidó himself has promised to call elections within six to twelve months, when Venezuela's Constitution would force him to do so within thirty days. He is not yet president and already wants to violate his country's Constitution. The EU must be an instrument in the service of peace and dialogue, not to fuel wars.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Madam President, I voted against the Resolution on the situation in Venezuela because, unfortunately, we are once again encountering a European Union which brazenly crosses the red line of respect for international law.  Today, the European Union once again subordinates it to the United States and sided with the war bloc with Trump, Duke and Bolsonaro, who encourage a glorious coup and military intervention. Flaunting cynicism they try to justify their position by appealing to the defence of human rights. Those same ones that are violated in Morocco, Israel and Saudi Arabia with their consent.  Let's be clear: your only interest is oil. You don't mind staining your hands with oil blood. If you were so interested in the Venezuelan people, withdraw sanctions and blockade.  Today the European Union again loses legitimacy. They would better be placed in the bloc of constructive dialogue and peace, and therefore in respect of international law, and next to the United Nations Security Council.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, today the European Parliament has sent a clear and clear message: in Venezuela the Maduro regime is killing people on the street because they disagree with its views. In Venezuela people are being tested by the deprivation of basic goods and freedoms. Journalists are being persecuted and imprisoned in Venezuela. In Venezuela our values, our European values, those that unite us and we are here are tested. It is therefore necessary to take the lead as a Parliament, calling for the recognition of the interim President, the interim leadership, which will lead to free fair and credible elections. It is necessary to call on the Council to move immediately and coherently. No doubt, no qualms, no selective affinity with the Maduro regime can and must not diminish the determination of the European Union. Europe and Maduro do not go together. All Venezuelan citizens must hear this, feeling the support of the European Union.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: GUE/NGL Group. – The European United Left voted against the Resolution on the situation in Venezuela presented by the PPE Group, Social Democrats and Liberals. Of course. Because it is a resolution that recognizes Juan Guaidó, the coupista, as president. And it does so because, as we all know, the European Union is very concerned about human rights and therefore funds torture centres for migrants in Libya, builds fences with concertinas or prevents NGO ships from going out to sea to rescue people. He is very concerned about human rights, of course, but in Venezuela.  Another argument for recognising the coupist is the European Union's strong appreciation for democracy. And that is why the European Union has a preferential economic agreement with a model as democratic as Saudi Arabia's absolutist monarchy.  The European Parliament believes that it has to support a person who has proclaimed himself president, without elections or anything, because Maduro is a tyrant who kills the hungry people. Not like the President of Sudan, with whom the European Union has signed several agreements in recent months, he has only two search and capture orders from the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity.  In addition, the European Parliament is dismayed that, according to its data, two million Venezuelans and Venezuelans are exiled. Instead, Israel is practically one more member of the European Union because there are only five million Palestinians in exile.  I think it is very clear that support for the coup in Venezuela has nothing to do with oil or the European Union's continuity to the United States, let alone Venezuela having a government that does not follow its neoliberal dictates.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this resolution on Venezuela, of which he was one of the signatories, because I believe that the European Union, which has not recognised the legitimacy of the early presidential election of 20 May 2018, should not wait any longer to explicitly and unanimously recognise Juan Guaidó as the legitimate interim president of Venezuela and should take advantage of the fact that it has five Member States among the 15 countries sitting on the UN Security Council to promote an understanding to which it the United States, Russia and China cannot or do not want to arrive. Contrary to what Nicolás Maduro proclaims, it is not imperialism that wants new elections before 2025. This is a demand of their fellow citizens who rightly demand the return of democracy and the rule of law and the end of the corrupt narcostate that forces millions to emigrate or to cross borders daily to seek food and medicine for their children. As The High Representative Mogherini rightly said, these voices that massively call for democracy and the possibility of freely determining their fate cannot be ignored. I also believe that this house cannot fail to condemn the serious limitations of Civil Rights of Juan Guaidó imposed by the Supreme Court of Justice and call for the immediate release of journalists, including a European, arrested yesterday in Caracas by the sinister Bolivarian national intelligence service.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I abstained. I did not want to vote against it, so as not to enter into the rhetoric of defending the communist regime that we hear from the left of the chamber. It is clear that our 'red' colleagues are much more forgiving of totalitarian regimes if they share their values. And now they insist on legalism? I would like to recall how they voted on Moldova when they ordered the government to coup against a legal court ruling. In the same way, in sudan, we voted in favour of the government challenging judicial judgments. And suddenly such legalists.  But I also could not vote in favour, because, firstly, it is a total hypocrisy when, on a day when we are once again restricting the freedom of expression of Members in our own Parliament, we are once again instructing the world on freedom of expression. Secondly, I do not, in principle, support the writing by the European Parliament of resolutions in which we speak forever on every subject around the world without knowing it really well. And we are not called to do so. Parliament should be a right for Europeans, not to comment on current political issues.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Madam President, it should be crystal clear that the only possible way to overcome the present crisis is through dialogue between the government and the opposition. This resolution, which we just passed, goes in exactly the opposite direction, blocking such dialogue – contrary to what the Secretary—General of the United Nations has called for; contrary to what is in this morning’s news – that President Maduro is ready to engage in dialogue.  There is a terrible double standard in this resolution. It criticises the government for holding unilateral elections, for not consulting with anybody when they organise them; and then it totally supports another unilateral action by the opposition, declaring Guaido as President.  I find this a terrible fault by this Parliament. In taking such a decision, it is only deepening the crisis.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: –Madam President, credit where it’s due: the approach of this Chamber to the Venezuelan catastrophe has been exemplary and the leadership of Antonio Tajani has been visionary on this issue.  When I was growing up in South America in the ‘70s Venezuela was a country that people emigrated to. When Hugo Chávez took over in 1999 the GDP per head was still substantially above the regional average. Now we have seen the worst refugee crisis in the history of the Western Hemisphere – more than 3 million people displaced, inflation touching 10 million% annually.  Extraordinarily, there are people, including some in the Socialist and Communist groups in this House, as we’ve just heard, who still stand by the discredited tyrannical regime of the Chavista—Maduro claque. How many times do we have to go through this experience before we understand that the problem of socialism is not some glittering implementation. The story is the same every time. It begins with slogans about the people, it ends in tyranny, poverty and oppression.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, so-called state aid is an important factor in competition policy, and in this respect there have really been points and monsters. Many provisions and fines have been imposed, with the result that the shipbuilding industry has been destroyed in particular. The well-known shipbuilding industry in Greece, the Skaramaga Shipyards, has to pay 310 million euros in state aid. It is forbidden so far to build merchant ships – where? In Greece! When the largest merchant fleet has a Greek flag! At the same time, another company, LARCO, is forced by a court decision to repay EUR 135.8 million, resulting in a close. We believe that the policy on state aid should be changed; Finally, there should be a special scheme. The Greek economy is in crisis because of the memorandum. There should be special arrangements and a special scheme for Greece in the field of State aid.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, this report rightly raises concerns about certain businesses that escape paying their fair share due to mismatches between national tax systems. We need to stop the race to the bottom on corporate tax levels. Likewise, a digital services tax is crucial to ensure that the likes of Facebook and Amazon pay up until there is a permanent solution allowing profits to be taxed where value is created. Madam President, finally, it’s also just been pointed out to me that I may well be the final British MEP to ever speak in this Chamber in Brussels. So let me say that I am proud to be part of the greatest peace and prosperity project of modern times, and good friends never say goodbye. They simply say: ‘See you soon’.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This time, the annual report on competition policy was not as routine as usual. Perhaps because two very serious actors have been given a lot of time: on the one hand, the truck manufacturers who built the cartel to increase the prices for these vehicles on the European market and, on the other hand, Google, for example. I would like to point out that this agreement in the Chamber on the need to condemn the practice of raising prices, not ensuring competitiveness, despite some internal compatibility, is very often superficial. I would also remind you that competition policy must be oriented towards ensuring a level playing field for all actors in all sectors and that this is the cornerstone of the European social market economy. And under no circumstances can there be an agreement that wealthy entities, wealthy individuals in these conditions, are in any way privileged.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I chose to abstain on this report. While there are some elements in the report that are quite positive, I feel it goes beyond the scope of a report on EU competition policy by calling for the implementation of CCCTB and for the removal of the unanimity principle for votes on tax issues at the Council. Still, I support reports welcoming the Commission efforts to ensure the effective application of competition rules across the EU, and indeed the encouraging of a structured dialogue with the Commissioner for Competition and the efforts of the Commission to maintain close cooperation with Parliament on these matters. Finally, I welcome the call for the Commission to increase support for SMEs and to protect our rights in the event of unfair commercial practices, and indeed the call on the Commission to step up efforts to promote fair competition in the global market. As a Member of the European Parliament’s Committee on International Trade, I see these as crucial aspects towards a well-functioning global trading environment and for ensuring a level playing field for EU companies that operate in it.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, a fair competition policy is an important objective that we must pursue, so it was easy to vote in favour of the report. Large companies gain a significant and unfair competitive advantage over small and medium-sized enterprises by avoiding and circumventing taxes. Large companies seem to be playing by their own rules when they even take advantage of illegal state aid schemes. As the report states, tax avoidance is detrimental to honest taxpayers and public finances. It also threatens good governance, macroeconomic stability and social cohesion, as well as public confidence in the institutions of the Union and the Member States. There are also regions within the EU that have been involved in creating low-tax tax systems that distort competition for multinationals and rich individuals. Member States should abandon these unfair and harmful competition practices. Commissioner Vestager deserves recognition for his work on fairer competition and for the substantial fines imposed on large companies that have violated competition law.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – I voted in favour of this report because it is quite obvious that a large part of entrepreneurial endeavors in the European Union need special protection. We need to return to the principles of the common market and protect the entrepreneurship and skills of people who want to work and earn their money with honest work. For example, I can give the outrageous proposals in the so-called " mobility package, a package that hinders free competition, hinders the free market and tries to take business away from one country and from one entrepreneur and put it in the hands of others. In this particular case, when we talk about this package, the Mobility package or the Macron package, as it is known, we are talking about the attempt by entrepreneurs from the central Part of the European Union to take away without competition, distorting the free market, bread and business from entrepreneurs from Eastern Europe, which in the case of my country will mean more than half a million migrants, 500 thousand people, which cannot be allowed.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to explain my vote, which has been positive in relation to this draft report. We agreed yesterday, when discussing this report, that the text has undergone very significant positive changes compared to previous years, so I wanted to appreciate this while highlighting that the internal market, competition, is really at the heart of our thinking. Of course, the market that is open, where there are both market forces and the protection of consumer interests, where we want to avoid unfair competition.  So all of this, I think, affects the report very well, but moreover – and this is very important to me – it expresses the idea that markets must be environmentally friendly. I really appreciate this environmental aspect. The sustainability of our market forces in the long run is indeed very important. We cannot follow the principle of 'flood after us', and I really appreciate this report, which is why I supported it.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament interrupted.
